p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
PARLIAMENTARY REPRESENTATION
Member For Fadden
Issue of Writ

The SPEAKER (10:01): I inform the House that on 18 May 2023 I received a letter from the Hon. Stuart Robert, resigning his seat as the member for the electoral division of Fadden. I also inform the House that it is my intention to issue a writ on Monday 12 June 2023 for the election of a member to serve for the electoral division of Fadden in the state of Queensland to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of the Hon. Stuart Robert. The dates in connection with the by-election will be fixed as follows: close of rolls—Monday 19 June; close of nominations—Thursday 22 June; date of polling—Saturday 15 July 2023; return of writ—on or before Wednesday 20 September 2023.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:02): I present the 10th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracy Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 12 April 2023 and 10 May
1. The committee resolved to present the following 33 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 7 petitioners—regarding corrupt elections (EN4977)
From 14 petitioners—regarding the Reserve Bank of Australia (EN4978)
From 176 petitioners—regarding parliamentary democracy in Pakistan (EN4979)
From 9 petitioners—requesting the banning of euthanasia in Australia (EN4980)
From 4 petitioners—requesting the condensing of degrees down to minimum years (EN4982)
From 16 petitioners—requesting the abandonment of the production and use of fossil fuels (EN4984)
From 6 petitioners—requesting support for South Australian midwifery and nursing students (EN4985)
From 1212 petitioners—requesting the abolition of additional language testing for Australian education and training graduates (EN4987)
From 9 petitioners—requesting the abolition of State governments in Australia (EN4990)
From 13569 petitioners—regarding protected identity for veterans and their families (EN4991)
From 16 petitioners—regarding low emission coal power (EN4992)
From 12 petitioners—requesting Trikafta approval for 6-11 year olds in Australia (EN4994)
From 14 petitioners—regarding the deportation of an Australian permanent resident of 54 years standing (EN4995)
From 302 petitioners—requesting the banning of gambling advertising on television, radio and online (EN4998)
From 1322 petitioners—regarding the review for processing time for BIIP (EN4999)
From 62 petitioners—requesting a Royal Commission into Covid-19 prevention measures (EN5000)
From 217 petitioners—requesting a better visa pathway for parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents (EN5001)
From 620 petitioners—regarding the wind farm off the coast of Port Stephens (EN5004)
From 14 petitioners—requesting Federal Members of Parliament, Senators and Prime Ministers to pass a cognitive test (EN5008)
From 171 petitioners—regarding the signing of the WHO pandemic prevention, preparedness and response accord (EN5009)
From 4 petitioners—requesting the charging of a $2000.00 fine for unsolicited pictures (EN5010)
From 11 petitioners—requesting a Voice for the transgender community (EN5011)
From 5 petitioners—requesting the banning of mobile phones for kids under 16 (EN5013)
From 8 petitioners—regarding the removal of testicles to be recognised as a woman in law (EN5014)
From 11 petitioners—regarding human rights issues in China (EN5016)
From 36 petitioners—requesting the backdating of the commencement date of the age pension (EN5020)
From 163 petitioners—regarding the unfair feed-in tariff rate (EN5021)
From 21 petitioners—requesting the increasing of the minimum wage for under 18s (EN5023)
From 121 petitioners—regarding land homes farms staying in Australia hands (EN5024)
From 25 petitioners—requesting that a national firearms registernot be created (EN5026)
From 139 petitioners—requesting an inquiry into the WHO pandemic treaty (EN5028)
From 572 petitioners—requesting a public referendum on rejecting amendments to the International Health Regulation (EN5029)
From 62 petitioners—requesting the inclusion of remuneration, with superannuation listed separately in job advertisements (EN5030)

span.span: 2. The following 34 ministerial responses to petitions were rece
Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 10 May 2023

p.span: From the Minister for Finance to a petition requesting the development and enforcement of a code of conduct for the Parliament of Australia (EN2597)
From the Minister for Emergency Management to a petition requesting the reintroduction of COVID-19 supplement payments for people on Australian Government income support (EN2954)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting the government to introduce Magnitsky-style sanctions legislation (EN3036)

From the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations to a petition regarding accommodation standards for workers in the Seasonal Worker Programme and the Pacific Labour Mobility (PALM) Scheme (EN3223)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting a full size Macrocell mobile phone tower or equivalent for Tarrawingee (EN3946)

From the Minister for Home Affairs to a petition requesting that the Australian Government designate the United Russia Party as a terrorist organisation, ban members of the United Russia Party from entering Australia, freeze their assets in international jurisdictions and nominate the Ukrainian humanitarian aid organisation as a benefactor of such assets transfer (EN4088)
From the Minister for Finance to a petition requesting to stop the Digital Identity Legislation and cease attempts to mandate Digital ID via myGov (EN4090 and EN4588)

From the Minister for Home Affairs to a petition requesting that the Australian Government designate the Russian Government and its armed forces as terrorist organisations for the purposes of the Criminal Code Act 1995(EN4333)
From the Minister for Home Affairs to a petition regarding Australian women and children in northeast Syria (EN4526)

From the Minister for Home Affairs to a petition requesting that the Australian Government designate the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) as a terrorist organisation under the Criminal Code Act 1995(EN4547)
From the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury to a petition requesting to make diesel cheaper than unleaded petrol (EN4551)
From the Minister for Home Affairs to a petition requesting that the Australian Government designate the current Russian Government as a terrorist regime (EN4562)
From the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury to a petition regarding Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) fees for Regional Visa holders (EN4599)
From the Minister for Sport to a petition regarding a Royal Commission into abuse in sports (EN4603)
From the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury to a petition regarding the diversity of Australian owned products within the food and grocery sector (EN4636)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting more flexible aged care services for small rural facilities (EN4652)

From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting to substitute the Pre-Employment Structured Clinical Interview (PESCI) and supervision for the Australian Medical Council's (AMC's) clinical examination as a pathway to general registration for international medical graduates (IMGs) (EN4677)
From the Minister for Early Childhood Education to a petition regarding early childhood education and care (ECEC) providers charging fees when children are absent due to illness (EN4680)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding the question of Palestinian Statehood (EN4681)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting to restore funding for PCR testing (EN4688)
From the Minister for Emergency Management to a petition regarding disaster relief funding for the local government area of Cabonne in NSW (EN4701)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding regulation over private alcohol and drug rehabilitation treatment centres (EN4704)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding China's application to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) (EN4711)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding medicinal use of marijuana in Australia (EN4713)
From the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations to a petition regarding changes to sick leave (EN4716)

From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting the Australian Government to reverse the $0.50 indexation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) concessional card co-payment (EN4744)
From the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to a petition regarding revised requirements for the importation of dogs and cats into Australia (EN4756)
From the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government to a petition regarding rail freight electrification (EN4759)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting increased Australian military support to Ukraine (EN4763)
From the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister to a petition requesting the Australian Government change the Australian National Anthem to 'I Am Australian' (EN4766)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting to ban companies convicted of carrying out illegal gain-of-function research (EN4775)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting to restrict energy drink sales for persons under 16 years of age (EN4778)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition regarding the cancellation of the Cashless Debit Card (CDC) in the Ceduna region (EN4783)

From the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government to a petition regarding the 'Sealing Roads in the Dandenong Ranges and Surrounds (Sealing Roads) projects' (EN4785)
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:02): I present the following 33 petitions:
Elections

Election exemption. Videos are now flow around social media showing. Polling booth workers removing ballots at dozens of booths put them in private cars with comments we are taking them to be counted before election night. This is a sign of corruption.we their for would like exempt to vote and fines removed
We therefore ask the House to exempt people from vote. And Remove fines . If elections are corrupt why vote. It now has been proven elections are rigged
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN4977)
Reserve Bank of Australia
A 2008 GFC credit crunch has been set into concrete already, yet the RBA ignores the bank collapses overseas & continues to put interest rates up in Australia.
Crashing the Australian economy is either deliberate or it's RBA incompetence, in my opinion. If it's deliberate, the House needs to find out why?
We therefore ask the House to investigate whether the RBA should be scrapped & replaced with another model that works.
As regards a Ministers decision, it's a simple yes/no response.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4978)
Pakistan: State Elections

Apex Court of Pakistan Supreme Court SC (Aus Equivalent High Court) made it mandatory for the caretaker governments in Punjab and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KPK) provinces to hold State elections within 90 days of the dissolution of the assemblies. The caretaker governments and governors in these states are blatantly refusing the electoral processes to be conducted within the time allowed in the Pakistan constitution, in contempt of the orders of the SC. The caretaker governments are allegedly tasked by the ruling elite, to cause serious human rights violations including the assassination of the former Prime Minister Khan, in order to prepare grounds being civil unrest and anarchy, for the postponement of the State elections to an uncertain date. In pursuance of the SC orders, the President of Pakistan provided the election date as 30 April 2023 in Punjab, which is now repealed by the Election commission of Pakistan unconstitutionally and against SC orders to a date in October 2023 anticipating that the current Hon. Chief Justice of SC will retire in September 2023. In KPK the Governor provided a date of 30 May 2023 and later redacted, yet again against the constitution. Parliamentary democracy in the 5th largest country in the world housing over 231 million people is at high risk.
We therefore ask the House to pass a motion or a declaration that free and fair elections be held in the most populated states of Pakistan within the time frame allowed by her constitution.
from 176 citizens (Petition No. EN4979)
Voluntary Assisted Dying

Religious opponents of euthanasia believe that life is given by God, and only God should decide when to end it. Other opponents fear that if euthanasia was made legal, the laws regulating it would be abused, and people would be killed who didn't really want to die. During EOL care, ethical dilemmas may arise from situations such as communication breakdowns, patient autonomy being compromised, ineffective symptom management, non-beneficial care, and shared decision making.
Voluntary euthanasia is unnecessary because alternative treatments exist
Requests for voluntary euthanasia are rarely free and voluntary
Voluntary euthanasia denies patients the final stage of growth
Voluntary euthanasia undermines medical research
Hard cases make bad laws
Autonomy is important but never absolute
Voluntary euthanasia leads to euthanasia tourism
Voluntary euthanasia changes the public conscience
Voluntary euthanasia violates historically accepted codes of medical ethics
Voluntary euthanasia gives too much power to doctors
Voluntary euthanasia leads inevitably to involuntary euthanasia
We therefore ask the House to ban and illegalise euthanasia across all the states of Australia
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN4980)
Education
Hi :)

I'm not sure how many hours people actually spend at uni to get a bachelors degree but I personally would rather spend 80 hours a week studying then only spending 15 hours. If I could do a degree I'd rather finish it ASAP then drag it out. Life is short. Studying isn't hard manual labor therefore no excuse.
Tradies should be taught by teachers not other tradies.
We therefore ask the House to condense and revise the duration of degrees/ apprenticeships.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4982)
Fossil Fuel Industry
Abandonment of fossil fuels

We therefore ask the House to immediately start to develop, and as soon as possible implement, a plan that will see Australia's exit from fossil fuel production for both domestic use and export sales, in the medium term; that is within 8 to 10 years
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN4984)

subdebateinfo.title: Universities: Nursing and Midwifery Training Placements

p.span: Universities: Nursing and Midwifery Training Placements

As many are aware the government have recently made changes to support new and incoming nursing and midwifery students to try and reduce the workplace shortages across Australia. They are reducing or clearing the HECS debt and going to financially support new students while on placement which is definitely a move in the right direction. But what about us, the current students? Those who are passionate about healthcare and struggling to survive, completing a minimum of 800 hours (1600 hours for those completing a double degree) of full time unpaid placement while being expected to maintain our studying. Each semester we are working full time including weekends / night duty and public holidays. Many students cannot afford to even complete placements due to the additional costs of transport, parking (so we don't have to walk kilometres in the dark), the rising cost of living and occasionally accommodation when we are unable to be placed close to our residence. We, students can already identify where the healthcare system is failing nurses and patients. We are compromising not only our own safety with the ridiculous travel commitments and working hours but also the safety of others including our patients. You beg for us to join the workforce, say you need us but we burning out, loosing hope and giving up before we even get there.
We therefore ask the House to financially support current nursing and midwifery students while on clinical placement not only future students.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4985)
Skilled Migration

I, the undersigned, respectfully request that the Australian parliament remove the need for English testing of overseas-born Australian-educated graduates for immigration, professional registration, and further study. We believe this additional testing is a form of discrimination that undermines Australian universities and other vocational training institutes' quality of education and training.

Overseas-born Australian-educated graduates have demonstrated their English competency while studying at Australian universities and vocational training centres. These students have passed rigorous academic and training requirements and have obtained degrees/qualifications from Australian institutions. The additional English testing creates unnecessary hurdles for these graduates and unfairly disadvantages them in immigration, professional registrations, and the job market.

Furthermore, we believe that the additional English testing creates an unnecessary financial burden for these graduates who have already invested significant time and resources into their education in Australia. This testing also sends a negative message to potential students who may be discouraged from studying in Australian universities due to the additional testing requirements.

We therefore ask the House to remove the need for English testing of overseas-born Australian-educated or trained graduates for immigration, professional registration, and further study and to promote fair and equal immigration and job opportunities for all graduates. We believe this action will uphold the reputation of Australian universities and promote a diverse and inclusive society.
Thank you for your attention to this matter.
from 1,212 citizens (Petition No. EN4987)
Australian Constitution

Australia has three levels of Government for a population close to 26.5 million people. There are over 500 Local councils each with an average Nine elected councilors. Six State Governments and two Territory parliaments with 582 elected members in Thirteen houses. One Federal government with 76 senators and 151 members of the House of Representatives.
One could also argue a fourth level being Crown Governors both Federal and each state.
We are probably the most over governed country.
The subsequent cost to Australian citizens has increased exponentially with, in some years over 14% increase in public servant sectors.

We therefore ask the House to review this petition and requests that the Federal government review the enormous increase in the Public Servant sectors and consider a plan to abolish State government and duplicated government bodies in favour of a more equitable two layer of Government.

It is proposed that Government should be closer to the people, therefore an increased more professional local government taking over the roles of state management. Directed and managed by an overarching Federal government. Federal Government providing funding and national standard laws thus eliminating state by state differences in laws, education, medical, aged care, road rules and other variable issues.
Whilst it is recognised that this would necessitate a change in the constitution and a major rethink of the way Australia operates.
As Australia ultimately moves to an independent republic this proposal would dovetail with those intentions.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN4990)
Defence Personnel

The recent national and international publication of the full name, picture and further identity details of an SAS soldier, accused of a criminal offence in relation to a war crimes, has exposed a critical gap in the responsible protections needed for our Veterans and their family members. Projections that are otherwise afforded to sex offenders within Australia. Protections that our Special Forces Veterans are told they are afforded with their protected identity status during service. However, this protected identity status is not currently enshrined in federal legislation and therefore not currently legally enforceable.
Legislation is needed immediately And must be an absolute priority for all elected Members of Parliament Senators.

We therefore ask the House to immediately pass legislation to protect the identities of our current and former serving special forces personnel, and all Australian Defence Force personnel accused of any crimes or investigations arising from any operational service. To afford our Veterans and their families protection from the existential threats that may arise from such circumstances, and to ensure our Veterans and their families are afforded due process and the presumption of innocence free from any public or media influence prior to the conclusion of all final judiciary proceedings.
from 13,569 citizens (Petition No. EN4991)
Energy
TO ALLOW BUILDING LOW EMISSION COAL POWER NOW!
WE ARE A SMALL POLLUTING COUNTRY TO MAKE ANY DIFERENCE TO THE WORLD TEMPATURE!
SO LABOR & GREENS WILL BAN ALL COAL & GAS SO WHERE WILLTHE GOV. GET THE MONEY TO FUND ALL THE WELFARE & THE HUGE BEURACRACIES?
YOU WILL MAKE ALL AUSTRALIANS ENERGY POOR & OUR STANDARD OF LIVING TO DROP!
PLEASECNA THE LABOR/GREENS SHOW US THE SCIENTIFIC PROOF OF THE GLOBOL WARMING AUSTRALIA IS RESPINSIBLE FOR COMPARE DOT CHINE OR INDIA?
We therefore ask the House to WE DEMAND NEW LOW EMISSIONS COAL POWER & GAS USAGE & EXPLORATION NOW

ENOUGH OF THE PRETEND CLIAME CHANGE WE HAD OVER 30 YEARS OF DOOMS DAY OF CLIMATE CHANGE & NOTHING HAS EVENTUATED SO WE DEMAND THESE STUPID UNSCIETIFIC POLATICNS STOP THE LIERS 7START THE CONSTRUCTION OF LOW EMISSIONS COAL POWER & ALLOW US THE GAS SUPPLES TO CONTINUE AS ALL GOVERNEMENT MUST SUPPLY TO THEIR PEOPLE FOR THEIR WELL BEING!
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN4992)
Cystic Fibrosis

I am the distressed mother of a 9 year old child with Cystic Fibrosis (CF). I am writing to you because I have serious concerns about the Australian Government's decision to delay the release of the miracle drug, Trikafta, to 6-11 year old Australian children living with CF. In my son, Ralph's, case, gaining access to Trikafta may be a matter of life or death. Ralph's diagnosis is further complicated by Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), Attention Deficit Disorder (ADD), Attention Deficit Hyperactive Disorder (ADHD) and Sensory Processing Disorder (SPD). These disorders significantly impact his ability to focus on the treatment required to manage CF (1.5 hours every morning and another 1.5 hours every night). As you can imagine, this is detrimental to Ralph's quality of life as it severely affects his schooling, social development and confidence. I feel as though I am watching my son's life force and spark for life slowly fading away before my eyes.
I urge you to put Trikafta at the top of your priority list so that 500 Australian children can quickly receive the medication that was recommended by the PBAC over 4 months ago.

Not only is Trikafta needed NOW for young Australian children, it is an embarrassment to Australia that Trikafta will be available to children aged 6-11 in New Zealand from 1st April, yet children living with Cystic Fibrosis in Australia go unheard.
We therefore ask the House to list Trikafta for 6-11year olds on the PBS.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN4994)
Taylor, Mr Julian Richard

The deportation of Australian permanent residents appears to be random and motivated by reasons not detailed in Direction 99 or similar. This case of Julian Taylor shows this clearly. He came to Australia as a 4 year old, lived here 54 years, holds 4 degrees in Engineering, Accounting, Mathematics and Economics, worked as an engineer and a maths/physics teacher, has an Australian daughter and partner. He has never shown violence, sexual, child or spousal abuse, drug use or anything similar yet the Minister claims he fails the criteria to stay in the country. Clearly the Minister's decision is wrong.

We therefore ask the House to seek an explanation from the Minister of Immigration as to how and why Julian Taylor—an individual who far exceeds any criteria of assessment—was deported from Australia within three hours of the Minister making his decision to deny him the reinstatement of his visa. That is, he had one hour to pack 54 years of residence in Australia.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4995)
Gambling Advertising

Recent data shows that an average of 948 gambling advertisements were broadcast each day in Victoria on free-to-air television alone. Three in four Australians have gambled at least once in the past 12 months and of those, almost half (46%) are classified as at risk of harm from betting.

We therefore ask the House to prohibit the advertising of licensed interactive wagering service (such as online and telephone betting) on television, radio, online and other platforms. The government must act quickly to prohibit predatory advertising practices of the gambling industry.
from 302 citizens (Petition No. EN4998)
Business Innovation and Investment Visa

We petition the Australian Parliament to address the unjustified and extended processing times for the Business Innovation & Investment Program, specifically for the Permanent stage. Many business visa applicants have made significant investment into Australian businesses and created many employment opportunities for local Australians during their provisional stage. However, after 28/10/2022, the processing time for their Permanent application has been significantly extended up to 35 months, with the Investor Stream does not even have a processing timeframe.

We therefore ask the House to urge the Government to conduct a review of the processing time for Business Innovation & Investment Program and expedite the processing time of the BIIP Permanent visa application to adhere to a timeline of 12 to 24 months, which is consistent with the timeframe published prior to 28/10/2022. By doing so, the Government will effectively establish a just and equitable approach towards those investors and their families who have resided in Australia for an extended period and have made significant contributions towards the progress of businesses and the overall economic development of the country. These investors hold a strong desire to secure permanent settlement in Australia and to be a valuable and integral part of this remarkable nation.
from 1,322 citizens (Petition No. EN4999)
COVID-19: Response

Citizens of Australia have the right to know how government arrived at the decisions made to prevent the spread of Covid. Restrictions were placed on all aspects of Australian lives—social distancing, education, commerce, health and work choices. Other measures such as lock-downs and mask-wearing were enforced, and non-vaccinated citizens were prevented from working or were refused access to venues. Many citizens were forced to vaccinate in order to earn a living.
Ultimately, individual freedoms were sacrificed for the good of the whole, and it needs to be established that that sacrifice was justified.
We therefore ask the House to request a Royal Commission into government handling of the covid-19 pandemic.

We specifically ask the Royal Commission to request the health/scientific data and research that government relied on to formulate its covid handling measures, and how that information was used to arrive at decisions and plans.
We also ask that it review any lingering health measures still in place that prevents any Australians from going about their everyday lives.
from 62 citizens (Petition No. EN5000)
Sponsored Parent Visa

We urge the Australian government to improve the visa pathway for parents of citizens and permanent residents. The current system has lengthy processing times, high costs, and limited stays, negatively affecting Australian families. COVID-19 has exacerbated the separation of families, making it more urgent to take action.

Migrants are essential contributors to the Australian economy and community. Almost one-third of the population was born overseas, and half have at least one foreign-born parent. They have significantly contributed to the Australian workforce and driven innovation and growth. Allowing parents to stay in Australia longer will benefit their children, grandchildren, and the economy by avoiding expenditure on healthcare, education, and other services.

Additionally, having parents in Australia significantly impacts citizens' and permanent residents' mental health and well-being. Separation from loved ones can cause depression, anxiety, and stress, decreasing productivity and increasing healthcare costs. Improving the visa system for parents is crucial for the well-being of Australian families and the economy.
We urge the house to take action and recognise the significant contribution migrants have made and continue to make to our society.
We therefore ask the House to :
1-Allow longer stays on Visitor Visas.
2-Increase the annual capacity of Parent and Contributory parent visas and speed up the processing times.
3-Create a permanent residency pathway for parents with only one Australian Citizen or Permanent resident child settled in Australia.
4-Reinstate the Medicare eligibility for Onshore Parent and Contributory Parent visa applicants.
5-Provide cheaper and longer temporary visas, for parents of Australian Citizens or Permanent residents.
from 217 citizens (Petition No. EN5001)
Renewable Energy
This petition is opposing the Climate Change and Energy Minister Chris Bowen's plans to build an offshore windfarm off the coast of Newcastle and Port Stephens.
Chris Bowens plans were revealed on his recent visit to the Hunter region.
The proposal is for at least 130 wind turbines with the possibility of more in the future.

The proposal puts them between 10km and 30km off the pristine coastline of Port Stephens. They can be up to 260m in height, by admission of the consultation department, they will be visible from shore.
This will not only be damaging to tourism but will also impact fishing, shipping and marine life.
We therefore ask the House to
Halt the proposal of the wind farm,
Provide greater community engagement and information, the consultation provided was insufficient, with questions unable to be answered.
If the community does not want this project to go ahead, we ask the House to scrap this project.
from 620 citizens (Petition No. EN5004)
Members of Parliament
President Biden clearly isn't of sound mind in my opinion, & the result is the US is destroying itself, to the detriment of the world.

We therefore ask the House to request a new law (or alter the Australian Constitution) to mandate any potential MP, Senator, PM pass a cognitive test to prove they're of sound mind before holding office.
As regards a decision by a Minister it's a simple yes/no answer.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN5008)
World Health Organization

The 'W.H.O. Pandemic prevention, preparedness and response accord' seeks to bind under International Law, member states including Australia to abide by its dictates, mandates and guidelines in the event of a future pandemic.
Given the W.H.O.'s disgraceful, incompetent and ineffectual handling of the Covid19 pandemic, this organisation cannot possibly be trusted or relied upon to dictate how pandemics should be handled.

The W.H.O.'s use of censorship in collusion with tech companies and mainstream media, its failure to properly investigate Covid-19's origin, and its promotion of lockdowns & inadequately tested medical products now found to be ineffective and unsafe, is a prime example of why it cannot be trusted.

We therefore ask the House to vehemently oppose any moves to sign Australia up to the "W.H.O. Pandemic prevention, preparedness and response accord" so that any future pandemic response is not tied to an incompetent and corrupt unelected bureaucratic body whose interests do not align with Australia's respect for human rights and our national interest.
W.H.O.'s misinformed advice should remain just that, and not a legally binding directive.
from 171 citizens (Petition No. EN5009)
Cybercrime
It is illegal to post private pictures of other people so why is it ok to send unsolicited and unwanted pictures to someone's personal DM?

Consent is becoming more and more important in today's society. Unwanted physical sexual attention is banned. It is always important to get consent so why does the rules not apply to when it comes towards unwanted pictures?
Violence towards women and sexual assault is very common and needs to stop! We need to take action on even aspect! Help put an end to sexual assault and violence towards women by banning pictures.
We therefore ask the House to put a Law to ban sending unsolicited images
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5010)
Australian Constitution

The push for the Voice in regards to the Aboriginal community has been admirable, but it's time to also acknowledge the vulnerability and torment of the transexual and transgender community who are arguably more oppressed and vilified by those with the inclination to do so. The trans community desperately needs a Voice, especially when you consider their significant issues with suicide and exposure to extreme bigotry which dwarfs all other oppressed groups within Australia. One only has to consider how amplified the bigotry experienced by being a transexual as an Aboriginal, for example, to realise the desperate need for a transexual/transgender Voice to Parliament. If you were to count the extended LGBTQ+ community, this encompasses a significant percentage of the population who encounter discrimination and sexuality based hatred on a daily basis. Unlike Aboriginal people, the LGBTQ+ community also suffer consistent alienation and abuse from their own families. It would be wrong to give one oppressed community a Voice without also then offering the transgender community a Voice to Parliament in the same fashion.
In making decisions, the government should also be forced to hear the Voice of the trans community.
We therefore ask the House to support an alteration to the constitution that establishes a transgender/transexual voice?
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN5011)
Telecommunications

Mobile phones are very dangerous if in the wrong hands. Kids under 16 shouldn't have their own mobile phones. The problems are obvious like mental illness, grooming, bullying, brain washing, poor school achievement, etc, etc.
We therefore ask the House to request a new law to ban kids under 16 from having a mobile phone outside the family home.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5013)
Gender And Sexual Orientation
A woman cannot have testicles that's impossible.
We therefore ask the House to request a new law, so only those born as biological men can be recognised in law as a woman, provided they have had both testicles removed permanently.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN5014)
Human Rights: China
As China commits serious human rights crimes in Xinjiang, Tibet and Hong Kong, it simultaneously persecutes Falun Gong and suppresses human rights in mainland China to suppress critical voices

We therefore ask the House to I think the Australian government should impose severe sanctions on ordinary Chinese officials and senior officials suspected of human rights violations, freeze their bank accounts and ban entry to Australia. At the same time, cut off all ties between human rights violators and Australia. It is clear that dialogue on human rights is useless, and we should use sanctions to safeguard human rights. And our sanctions should be directly imposed on members of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China Central Committee in China. Thanks!
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN5016)
Age Pension
In 2020 to 2022, the COVID-19 Pandemic trapped tens of thousands of Australians overseas, including a number of Australian Seniors eligible to claim the Age Pension.

Unfortunately, such claims were invalid due to Section 29 of the Social Security (Administration) Act 1999 "a claim made at a time when the claimant is not an Australian resident or is not in Australia is taken not to have been made."
In many cases this resulted in these Australians having no source of income for over 5 months and subsequently left in debt.
The present law is unjust, unfair and discriminatory. It is dividing COVID-19 victims into two categories- The worthy and the unworthy.

We therefore ask the House to amend Section 29 of the Social Security (Administration) Act 1999 with the inclusion of an exception that grants a limited discretionary power to the Minister for Social Services, which would enable them to make a determination, on a case-by-case basis, as to whether a valid intent to claim for the Age Pension was established, and that this claim is then deemed to have been made earlier than the date the claim was actually made i.e backdated.
This backdating would basically follow the spirit and form of the Social Security (Administration) (Class of Persons—Intent to Claim) Determination 2018.

This exception for Australian Seniors should cover- pandemic induced travel restrictions, natural disasters, war, civil unrest, wrongful arrest, wrongful imprisonment, hospitalisation, disease, illness, injury, et cetera.
from 36 citizens (Petition No. EN5020)
Renewable Energy
I installed solar panels to reduce my electricity as well as to save the environment. Australian government has been encouraging more houses to have solar power to go more environment friendly too.

For the first 4 years I have made substantial credits in my electricity bill because I had made much more power than I used but saying that the supplier's cost of producing electricity has gone up, they raised their rate but decreased feed-in rate.
They buy my electricity cheaper than before and re-sell it more expensively to the customers? What kind of mathematics is that?
Now I have to pay for my electricity bill even though I make 5 times more electricity than I use.
I understand their cost raise can increase their rate but why my electricity should go cheaper? I strongly believe that the customers are playing a seriously unfair game.

We therefore ask the House to look into this ridiculous situation and make changes on feed-in rate so that more houses without solar panels would join to go solar thinking it's more beneficial for themselves and for the world. At this point there is not much of attraction if we are having losing games.
from 163 citizens (Petition No. EN5021)
Wages

As a first world country no one should be subjected to slavery but it still happens today. Paying under 18s less money due to their age is a violation of human rights and is not good enough. It's not fair to children who work as hard if not harder than 18 years and adults trying to get a low skilled job when their over 18. Children go to school for 30 hours a week, then study and do sports and then work and it's not fair that they aren't being paid properly it's illegal and is slavery. Employers only want to give them jobs cause it's cheaper to pay them meaning adults struggle to get a low skilled job. Kids don't get paid to study, and many don't need to go to school because many won't be using their brains to make money.
We therefore ask the House to ban below minimum wage for minors.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN5023)
Foreign Investment
To many foreign people are coming to Australia buying land .houses. farms .drive up prices of land .houses .farms . Australia citizen can't afford to buy
We therefore ask the House to ban foreign ownership of houses land farms in Australia.other countries ban foreign ownership why doesn't Australia
from 121 citizens (Petition No. EN5024)
Gun Control

Australia does not need a national firearms register. Police already have channels to allow them access to firearms data from other states. This is part of a worrying trend in which the Federal Government is increasingly centralising data collection. The threat of right-wing or religious extremism is always trotted out as an excuse when the Government wants to get policy through unopposed.
We therefore ask the House to not establish a national firearms register.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN5026)

subdebateinfo.title: Convention, Agreement or Other International Instrument on Pandemic Prevention, Preparedness and Response

p.span: Convention, Agreement or Other International Instrument on Pandemic Prevention, Preparedness and Response
To ensure that Australians won't lose their ability to make their own health decisions.

We therefore ask the House to investigate the Pandemic treaty and ensure that this pandemic treaty is not going to take away Australia's Sovereignty and individuals right to choose their own health outcomes and freedom of choice and represents the Australian taxpayers and not the vested interests of unelected overseas interests.
from 139 citizens (Petition No. EN5028)
International Health Regulations

We the people of Australia are concerned that Parliament has not discussed (and no Public Referendum held) and will not have a say on the 307 proposed amendments to the International Health Regulations, AND the amendments to 5 Articles of the IHR that were ADOPTED by the 75th World Health Assembly on 27 May 2022.

The amendments that were adopted on 27 May 2022 have not been debated in or voted on by Parliament or the people. Australia has the authority to reject them under Article 61 of the IHR, but any such rejection must be within 18 months of their adoption.

Parliament and the people must be given the opportunity to vote on whether to reject the amendments that have already been adopted, and also the 307 proposed amendments that are currently being negotiated by Australian delegates to the 76th World Health Assembly.
We therefore ask the House to hold Parliamentary debate and a Public Referendum on whether to reject the amendments that have already been adopted, and also the 307 proposed amendments
from 572 citizens (Petition No. EN5029)
Employment: Remuneration

A job's viability and pay rate are important determinants of whether a candidate applies for and accepts a position. In many job adverts, neither the rate of pay nor the compensation package is specified. 61% and 67% of respondents to studies conducted by LinkedIn and Glassdoor, respectively, indicated that compensation was the most essential aspect of a job description. There is a rising global push to make salary transparency not merely the new standard but also the law, according to a BBC article. In accordance with current regulations regarding pay secrecy, job advertisements, flexible work and fixed-term contracts, and gender equality, job advertisements must include the rate of pay or total compensation. I also believe it is misleading for advertisements to include superannuation in hourly, weekly, or annual rates. Retirement benefits should not be included in the compensation package or pay rate. Not including the rate of pay or remuneration in a job advertisement makes it very difficult for prospective employees to make informed decisions and decide whether they will go through the (at times) excruciating process of applying for jobs, which can include phone interviews, zoom interviews, assessments, group assessments, psychometric testing, and in-person interviews, only to find out that the job is not viable.

We therefore ask the House to consider amending the Fair Work Act to mandate that remuneration be published in job advertisements and that superannuation must be listed separately rather than being included in the rate of pay.
from 62 citizens (Petition No. EN5030)
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:02): I present the following 34 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Parliament
Dear Ms Templeman

I am writing in response to correspondence of Mr Ken O'Dowd dated 24 May 2021, addressed to Senator the Hon Simon Birmingham, Minister for Finance, regarding Petition EN2597 to develop and enforce a code of conduct for the Parliament of Australia.

Everyone has the right to a safe and respectful workplace, and we want to uphold the highest standards of workplace behaviour in the Parliament of Australia in line with the expectations of the Australian public. Establishing clear and consistent standards of conduct for Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces was a key recommendation of Set the Standard: Report on the Independent Review into Commonwealth Parliamentary Workplaces (the Set the Standard Report) (https://humanrights.gov.au/set-standard-2021) prepared by the Australian Human Rights Commission. Further detail on the Government's progress towards developing behaviour standards for Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces and codes of conduct for parliamentarians and staff is set out below. The Set the Standard Report made 28 recommendations for systemic and cultural change to make Parliament House and Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces safe and respectful places to work.

The Albanese Government is committed to improving the standard of behaviour in Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces, and is working across Parliament to implement all 28 recommendations of the Set the Standard Report.

The Government acknowledges the findings in the Set the Standard Report that an unacceptably high rate of people, particularly women, in Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces have experienced bullying, sexual harassment or actual or attempted sexual assault at work. This misconduct is unacceptable. As the Prime Minister and I reiterated in Parliament on 8 February this year, the Government is committed to working with the Parliamentary Leadership Taskforce and across the Parliament to implement all 28 recommendations made by the Set the Standard Report to ensure that our Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces meet the expectations of the community.

span.span: Progress on the development of codes of conduct for all Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces

p.span: Establishing codes of conduct for parliamentarians and staff was a key recommendation of made by the Set the Standard Report. In February 2023, both Houses of Parliament endorsed draft Behaviour Codes for Australian Parliamentarians and for staff employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, as well as Behaviour Standards everyone who works in parliament, pending the establishment of the advisory and enforcement regime. Sex Discrimination Commissioner Kate Jenkins described the endorsement of the codes as "an historic moment", noting that "Federal Parliament has never had codes of conduct" and that codes of conduct are "an important tool to help ensure parliament is a safe, respectful workplace."

The draft codes endorsed by Parliament were developed the Joint Standing Committee on Parliamentary Standards (Committee). Both draft codes for parliamentarians and for staff underscore that ensuring Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces meet the highest standards of integrity, dignity, safety and mutual respect is a shared responsibility, and cover respect, diversity, prohibited behaviours (including bullying, harassment, sexual harassment, assault and all forms of discrimination) and complaints under the code (among other things). The development of the codes was informed by public hearings held in September and November 2022, as well as more than 40 submissions to the Committee. The draft codes, Committee's report, and submissions made to the Committee's inquiry are available on the Committee's website (https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Parliamentary_Standards)

One of the key recommendations of the Set the Standard Report also being progressed by the Government is to establish an Independent Parliamentary Standards Commission (IPSC) to investigate alleged breaches of the codes of conduct. The Set the Standard Report recommended that the IPSC should be able to receive complaints, conduct investigations, make recommendations on sanctions and apply some sanctions to parliamentarians where there has been a breach of the codes of conduct.
The Prime Minister stated in the House of Representatives on 8 February 2023 that the Government was working across Parliament to establish the IPSC as a priority.

span.span: Conduct for Ministers and Ministerial Staff currently in effect

p.span: In addition, the Government has put in place strong codes of conduct for ministers and ministerial staff. The Code of Conduct for Ministers adopted by the Albanese Government in June 2022 sets out expectations for the conduct and behaviour of Ministers. The Code is underpinned by key principles that Ministers must act with due regard for integrity, fairness, accountability, responsibility and the public interest.

Ministers are expected to demonstrate they are complying with the high standards of conduct and, in doing so, living up to the expectations of the Australian public. Ministers, and their staff, are also now required to undertake mandatory training to ensure everyone contributes to creating safe and respectful workplaces.

Ministers are required to register their private interests publicly on the parliamentary Register of Members' or Senators' Interests. Ministers are also required to provide private interests declarations directly to the Prime Minister, and report any potential conflicts to the Cabinet Secretary.

Similarly, the Code of Conduct for Ministerial Staff set out expectations for conduct and behaviour of the personal and electorate staff employed by Ministers. Ministerial staff are required by the Code to behave honestly and with integrity, conduct themselves in a manner that supports a safe and respectful workplace for everyone, and disclose and take steps to avoid any conflicts of interest.

The multi-party Parliamentary Leadership Taskforce (PLT) is overseeing progress on the implementation of the Set the Standard Report's recommendations, including the recommendations to develop codes of conduct for Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces and to establish the IPSC. Updates on the status of each recommendation are published periodically on the PLT website (https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Leadership_Taskforce).

We have achieved significant progress in implementing the Set the Standard Report's recommendations to date. Of the 28 recommendations, six have been implemented, four have been partially implemented and 17 are in progress and ongoing. The Government has passed protections against age and disability discrimination, completed a review of the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984 and accepted in principle all 15 recommendations, and Parliament has changed its standing orders to facilitate more family-friendly hours.
I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Public Service, Katy Gallagher
Foreign Investment
Dear Chair

I refer to correspondence of 18 October 2021 to the former Treasurer, enclosing Petition EN2954, with eight signatures, calling for the reintroduction of COVID-19 supplement payments for people on Australian Government income support. This correspondence has now been referred to me as it falls under my responsibilities as the Minister for Emergency Management. I apologise for the delay in responding.

As referenced by this Petition, a number of Australian Government COVID-19 measures for people on income support ended in March 2021, including the JobKeeper wage subsidy and social security measures such as the Coronavirus Supplement for recipients of the JobSeeker Payment.

In reference to this Petition, I note that the Albanese Government continued a number of payments intended to support those affected by COVID-19 isolation requirements, including those on income support.

The Crisis Payment for National Health Emergency (COVID-19) was a one-off payment granted to income support recipients in severe financial hardship who, due to COVID-19, were required to isolate or care for a person who was required to isolate. The amount paid was equal to one week of the person's maximum basic rate of income support. The payment commenced on 25 March 2020 and ended on 1 October 2022. Around 1.7 million grants were paid costing around $580 million over the period.

The COVID-19 Disaster Payment was announced on 3 June 2021 and activated in states and territories as lockdowns progressed. It was a lump sum payment for those who had lost work or income as a result of a COVID-19 lockdown. Payments were phased out once a state or territory achieved 80 per cent of the population aged 16 years or older fully vaccinated, then abolished. All jurisdictions have reached the 80 per cent threshold and the payment is no longer available. Over 2.3 million individuals were supported under this payment to a total of over $12.85 billion.

The Pandemic Leave Disaster Payment (PLDP) was announced on 3 August 2020. The PLDP provided a lump sum payment to assist eligible workers when they were unable to attend work due to having to isolate, quarantine or care for someone who had to isolate or quarantine as required by their state or territory government. Following a unanimous decision by the National Cabinet on 30 September 2022 to end mandatory isolation requirements, the PLDP was ended on 14 October 2022. The PLDP supported over two million people to a total of over $2.3 billion.

The High-Risk Settings Pandemic Payment (HRSPP) replaced the PLDP on 15 October 2022, again, based on a unanimous decision by the National Cabinet. The HRSPP provided financial support for casual workers and those without leave entitlements in identified high risk settings, including aged care, disability care, aboriginal healthcare, hospital care and custodial settings. National Cabinet agreed the HRSPP would cease on 31 March 2023. As at 10 April 2023, over 44,000 claims in HRSPP have been paid to a total of over $32 million.

From 1 April 2023, Aged Care Worker COVID-19 Leave Payment grants are available to support permanent or casual aged care workers for older Australians most at risk of severe illness. The grants help to further protect people living in residential aged care, or those receiving home care packages, by allowing staff who test positive to COVID-19 to stay home while unwell. Providers of Australian Government-funded residential aged care homes and approved home care packages are able to apply for reimbursement for payments made from 1 April 2023, every three months through the Department of Health and Aged Care. Thank you for bringing Petition EN2954 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Emergency Management, Murray Watt
Human Rights
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for the referral of petition number EN3036 of 18 October 2022 (originally referred by Mr O'Dowd to then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Marise Payne) which calls on the then Government to introduce Magnitsky-style sanctions legislation.

The petition requests that the Government immediately enact a Magnitsky-style Act. The Autonomous Sanctions (Magnitsky-style and Other Thematic Sanctions) Amendment Act 2021 (which amended the Autonomous Sanctions Act 2011} was passed by Parliament on 2 December 2021 and commenced on 8 December 2021. Following this, the Government amended the Autonomous Sanctions Regulations 2011 to establish thematic sanctions regimes in relation to serious human rights violations and abuses, serious corruption and significant cyber incidents. The Autonomous Sanctions Amendment {Magnitsky-style and Other Thematic Sanctions) Regulations 2021 commenced on 21 December 2021.

I note the petition calls for the enactment of standalone Magnitsky-style legislation. The amendments to the Autonomous Sanctions Act 2011 and Autonomous Sanctions Regulations 2011 introduced Magnitsky-style sanctions into Australia's existing autonomous sanctions framework. Embedding the reforms in our existing autonomous sanctions framework avoided duplication and ensured consistency across sanctions regimes (including in regards to compliance and enforcement mechanisms and human rights safeguards}, making it simpler for businesses and other members of the community to comply with Australian sanctions laws.

I have made three tranches of thematic sanctions listings. The first tranche of sanctions on 13 individuals and two entities were made on 10 December 2022. Those sanctioned included seven Russian individuals involved in the attempted assassination of former opposition leader Alexei Navalny. Also sanctioned were two Iranian entities {Iran's Morality Police and the Basij Resistance Force) and six lraninan individuals, involved in the violent crackdown on protests following the death of Mahsa 'Jina' Amini and the continued oppression of the people of Iran.

The second tranche of sanctions on 16 Iranian individuals and one Iranian entity made on 1 February 2023 also focused on human rights abuses in Iran. Among those sanctioned were the Basij Cooperative Foundation, and senior law enforcement, political and military figures—including those within the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps {IRGC).

I imposed a third tranche of sanctions on a further 14 individuals and targeted financial sanctions on 14 Iranian entities responsible for egregious human rights abuses and violations in Iran. Among those subject to Magnitsky-style human rights sanctions are four members of the Morality Police who were responsible for the arrest, detention and ill- treatment of Mahsa 'Jina' Amini.

Sanctioned targets also include senior law enforcement, political and military figures, including within the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, involved in the violent crackdown on protests following the death of Ms Amini and the continued oppression of the people of Iran.

Australia also joined partners to impose targeted financial sanctions and travel bans on 13 Iranian individuals and targeted financial sanctions on one entity involved in the production and supply of drones to Russia. Iranian-made drones have been used by Russia to target Ukrainian civilians and civilian infrastructure.

The Government is also currently undertaking a legislative review of Australia's autonomous sanctions framework. The review is an opportunity to consider legislative reforms to further support the operation of autonomous sanctions, informed by public consultation.

Importantly, it will consider improvements to the framework to better support the Government's foreign policy objectives, as well as administrative and regulatory efficiencies to ensure sanctions compliance.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Penny Wong
Pacific Australia Labour Mobility Scheme
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021 to former Senator the Hon Zed Seselja, former Minister for International Development and the Pacific, regarding petition EN3223 on accommodation standards for workers in the Seasonal Worker Programme and the Pacific Labour Mobility (PALM) scheme. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me for reply.

The Australian Government is aware of the accommodation challenges facing the PALM Scheme, and the nation as a whole. PALM Approved Employers (AEs) are required under their Deed with the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations, to arrange accommodation for PALM workers, in accordance with standards set by the program, and cannot recruit workers without having an approved accommodation plan. In the PALM Scheme, this accommodation must meet minimum program requirements, including for cleanliness, security, comfort, and safety. The Department are consulting on improvements to accommodation settings as part of their consultation for a new Deed and Guidelines.

The Government has also established an Accommodation Working Group to develop solutions for PALM accommodation issues. The working group membership includes PALM AEs and industry representatives, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, state and local government representatives, Pacific and community support organisations, and Commonwealth representatives from the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts.

The working group will develop workable solutions to secure an adequate supply of suitable accommodation for PALM Scheme workers. The working group recently held its first meeting, with a forward agenda currently under development to guide future meetings.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Tony Burke
Telecommunications
Dear Chair

On 31 March 2022, the former Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Ken O'Dowd, referred Petition EN3946 to the f01mer Minister for Regional Communications, Senator the Hon Bridget McKenzie. This petition has been referred to me as this matter now falls under my responsibility as Minister for Communications. I sincerely apologise for the delay in responding. The petition from the previous Parliament was inadvertently marked as not needing a response during the change of government, and I unreservedly apologise for this oversight.

The petition has requested that the House of Representatives prioritise the delive1y of a reliable mobile phone service to Tarrawingee through a full-size Macrocell mobile phone tower or equivalent technology that provides reliable services to all residents of Tarrawingee and surrounds.
I understand the concerns raised in the petition and the need for regional communities, such as Tarrawingee, to have access to reliable mobile and internet services, particularly during emergencies.

I can advise that under Round 2 of the Regional Connectivity Program (RCP), Tarranwingee was selected as a location to receive a new Telstra macro cell mobile base station. Information on the Regional Connectivity Program can be found on the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts' website at www.infrastrncture.gov.au/rcp.

The RCP project will deliver improved handheld mobile coverage to Tarrawingee and the surrounding area, enabling improved mobile voice, wireless broadband and Internet of Things (IoT) network capability in a currently underserviced area. The project will create opportunities for economic growth in the town and broader Wangaratta Local Government Area, particularly to local Agriculture, Manufacturing and Tourism businesses. Additionally, the project will support better public safety, as well as delivering better access to health and education. It is anticipated the project will be completed in Q4 of 2024.

The Australian Government is committed to increasing connectivity, bridging the digital divide, improving mobile coverage and protecting communities against natural disaster. To this end, the Government has committed $2.2 billion to regional connectivity in the 2022-23 Budget over the next five years. This includes over $1.1 billion of investment in regional areas, under the Government's NBN policy, to provide full-fibre access to more than 660,000 homes and business in the regions currently relying on copper wire.

In addition, the Government has delivered $480 million to upgrade the NBN fixed wireless network by the end of 2024, which is also enabling improvements to NBN Sky Muster satellite services. This upgrade will provide access to higher speeds over an expanded NBN fixed wireless footprint or increased data limits and product inclusions on NBN Sky Muster satellite services.
The upgrade will deliver improved services for around one million premises in regional and remote Australia and in peri-urban areas.

As part of the $2.2 billion investment, the Government's Better Connectivity Plan for Regional and Rural Australia (the Plan) commits $656 million in further new measures to regional communications. This includes $400 million dedicated to boosting mobile coverage and resilience, $200 million for place-based connectivity solutions under two new rounds of the Regional Connectivity Program, $30 million for on-farm connectivity, $20 million for an independent audit of mobile coverage to better identify and target blackspots, and a $6 million boost in funding for the Regional Tech Hub, a platform serving as a trusted source of free and independent advice for regional Australians on technology.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Michelle Rowland
United Russia
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 enclosing Petition EN4088, with 893 signatures, requesting that the Australian Government designate the United Russia Party as a terrorist organisation, ban members of the United Russia Party from entering Australia, freeze their assets in international jurisdictions and nominate the Ukrainian humanitarian aid organisation as a benefactor of such assets transfer.

For an organisation to be listed as a terrorist organisation, the organisation must satisfy the legislative criteria set out in Division 102 of the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Criminal Code), namely that the organisation must be either directly or indirectly involved in the doing of a terrorist act, or advocating the doing of a terrorist act. It is the Government's longstanding practice not to comment on whether an organisation is being, or has been, considered for listing.

As you know, the Government has strongly condemned Russia's illegal and immoral, full-scale invasion of Ukraine, which remains a gross violation of international law. Australia's objective, along with our partners, is to empower Ukraine to resolve this conflict on its own terms.

For these reasons, the Australian Government has imposed targeted financial sanctions and travel bans on 981 persons and 108 entities, including members of the United Russia Party. Additionally, Australia has committed approximately AUD680 million in assistance to the Ukrainian Government and to Ukrainian people in need of humanitarian assistance. Since 23 February 2022, my Department has granted more than 10,000 visas to Ukrainians, with more :han 5,000 Ukrainians with these visas having since arrived in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4088 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Clare O'Neil
Personal Information and Privacy
MyGov
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 regarding Petition EN4090 and 6 February 2023 regarding Petition EN4588 asking the House of Representatives to stop the Digital Identity Legislation and cease attempts to mandate Digital ID via myGov.
The Albanese Government shares the petitioners' passion for ensuring that Australians have their privacy and security protected.
The Australian Government's Digital ID system is a simple, safe and secure way for Australians to choose to verify their identity and prove who they are online.
The Digital ID program has been underway since 2015 and is available to use today with over 10 million Australians already choosing to create a Digital ID through myGovlD.

These Digital IDs are being used along with over 1.5 million Australian businesses to access over 125 government services online. Digital ID improves access to services (particularly in remote areas) because it lets people apply for things like Tax File Numbers or Centrelink services entirely online, without travelling sometimes very long distances to a government shopfront.

Digital ID provides an optional way for people to access services without repeatedly providing their identity documents. This reduces the amount of data held by organisations on people using Digital ID, meaning that their data is safer from being hacked.

The Digital ID system (the System) follows a 'privacy by design' approach, with strong privacy and consumer protections. This includes security features which undergo rigorous assessment and testing.·
Providers within the System must be accredited under the Trusted Digital Identity Framework and meet strict requirements to protect users' privacy and security, and control against fraud.
This is important to safeguard the system with high privacy, consumer and governance standards and ensure the trust and confidence of Australians.

As the petitioners point out, I also understand that even with these protections in place, not everyone would want a Digital ID. It is important that Australians understand Digital ID is not mandatory. It is completely voluntary and based on consent.
Australians can keep using government services the same way they do now—whether that's online, on the phone or in person at a government shopfront.

The Albanese Government is committed to the success of Digital ID and the protections it offers to access government services online in a secure way, including safeguarding the data and personal information of Australians.

I will continue to consult with the community on these important reforms, and I thank you for bringing these petitions to my attention. I trust that this response provides the signatories assurance in the Government's Digital ID Program.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Finance, Katy Gallagher
Russia
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 enclosing Petition EN4333, with 2,753 signatures, requesting that the Australian Government designate the Russian Government and its armed forces as terrorist organisations for the purposes of the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Criminal Code).

For an organisation to be listed as a terrorist organisation, the organisation must satisfy the legislative criteria set out in Division 102 of the Criminal Code, namely that the organisation must be either directly or indirectly involved in the doing of a terrorist act or advocating the doing of a terrorist act. A nation state and its armed forces are not the kind of entities that are covered by the terrorist organisation provisions in the Criminal Code.

As you know, the Government has strongly condemned Russia's illegal and immoral, full-scale invasion of Ukraine, which remains as a gross violation of international law. Australia's objective, along with our partners, is to empower Ukraine to resolve this conflict on its own terms.

For these reasons, the Government has imposed targeted financial sanctions and travel bans on 981 persons and 108 entities, including senior members of the Russian Government and Russian Armed Forces. Additionally, Australia has committed approximately AUD680 million in assistance to the Ukrainian Government and to Ukrainian people in need of humanitarian assistance. Since 23 February 2022, the Department of Home Affairs has granted more than 10,000 visas to Ukrainians, with more than 5,000 Ukrainians with these visas having since arrived in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4333 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Clare O'Neil
National Security
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your correspondence of 28 November 2022 to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Penny Wong, enclosing Petition EN4526, with 18 signatures, concerning Australian women and children in northeast Syria. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Australian Government's approach to repatriations is driven by national security and safety considerations. The Government's overriding priority is the protection of Australians and Australia's national interest, informed by national security advice.

The decision to repatriate four Australian women and their 13 children was informed by individual assessments following detailed work by national security agencies. These individuals are continually assessed by Joint Counter Terrorism Teams—which includes the Australian Federal Police, Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and state law enforcement agencies.
I can assure you that Australia's security and the safety of the Australian community are the Australian Government's paramount concern.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4526 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Clare O'Neil
National Security
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 enclosing Petition EN4547, with 8,599 signatures, requesting that the Australian Government designate the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) as a terrorist organisation under the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Criminal Code).

For an organisation to be listed as a terrorist organisation, the organisation must satisfy the legislative criteria as set out in Division 102 of the Criminal Code. As an organ of a nation state, the IRGC is not the kind of entity that is covered by the terrorist organisation provisions in the Criminal Code.

As you know, the Australian Government has strongly condemned the ongoing deadly and disproportionate attacks against protesters in Iran, following the tragic death of Mahsa (Jina) Amini. The Government regularly raises Iran's significant discrimination against women and human rights violations in both Tehran and Canberra, as well as in multilateral fora. Australia has a longstanding bilateral relationship with Iran, which allows us to have frank discussions with the Iranian Government.
Australia has imposed thematic human rights 'Magnitsky'-style sanctions on
56 Iranian individuals and 23 Iranian entities since the protests began, including Iran's Morality Police and senior Iranian law enforcement and military officials.

This includes members of the IRGC. These sanctions encompass financial sanctions and travel bans on individuals, and financial sanctions on entities. Sanctions are one of the measures the Government employs to respond to human rights abuses and violations.

The Australian Government has also worked with partners to remove Iran from the Commission for the Status of Women and co-sponsored and advocated for the successful Human Rights Council resolution for the establishment of an independent fact-finding mission to investigate human rights violations in Iran.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4547 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Clare O'Neil
Diesel
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4551 on make diesel cheaper than unleaded petrol. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

In response to your request to make diesel cheaper than unleaded petrol, the Government is not currently considering a reduction in the fuel excise rate on diesel. The Government uses the revenue from the fuel excise collected from diesel to fund essential services that all Australians benefit from such as health, education, and defence.

The price of diesel in Australia has three main components: the international price of refined diesel, Australian Government taxes, and other costs of transporting and selling fuel (including a profit margin.

Australia currently has among the lowest retail diesel prices among all the OECD group of countries. However, the use of diesel in passenger cars both globally and in Australia is growing. While diesel is used as a motor vehicle fuel, it is also used in a number of industries including mining, rail and road transport, electricity generation and agriculture. The same supply and demand pressures have not generally occurred for petrol.

In its recent report, the ACCC has found that the key factors affecting diesel prices are reduced supplies of diesel from Russia, refinery strikes from France, combined with increased demand for heating in the northern hemisphere winter. Its most recent report can be found at: www.accc.gov.au/media-release/international-factors-kept-diesel-prices-siqnificantly-higher-than-petrol-prices.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Andrew Leigh
Russia
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 enclosing EN4562, with 223 signatures, requesting that the Australian Government designate the current Russian Government as a terrorist regime.

For an organisation to be listed as a terrorist organisation, the organisation must satisfy the legislative criteria set out in Division 102 of the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Criminal Code), namely that the organisation must be either directly or indirectly involved in the doing of
a terrorist or advocating the doing of a terrorist act. A nation state is not the kind of entity that is covered by the terrorist organisation provisions in the Criminal Code.

As you know, the Government has strongly condemned Russia's illegal and immoral, full-scale invasion of Ukraine, which remains a gross violation of international law. Australia's objective, along with our partners, is to empower Ukraine to resolve this conflict on its own terms.

For these reasons, the Government has imposed targeted financial sanctions and travel bans on 981 persons and 108 entities, including senior members of the Russian Government. Additionally, Australia has committed approximately AUD680 million in assistance to the Ukrainian Government and to Ukrainian people in need of humanitarian assistance. Since 23 February 2022, the Department of Home Affairs has granted more than 10,000 visas to Ukrainians, with more than 5,000 Ukrainians with these visas having since arrived in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4562 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Clare O'Neil
Migration: Housing
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN4599—Regional Visa Holders should not pay Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) fees. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.
Petition EN4599 raises concerns regarding the financial demands placed on regional visa holders due to the recent increase in fees for foreign investment in residential real estate.

Consistent with the Government's election commitment, foreign investment fees doubled from 29 July 2022. Such fees apply to all foreign investors (including temporary residents) under the definition provided in the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975, regardless of their visa type or location in Australia.

Foreign investment fees are an essential part of the foreign investment framework and support the cost of its administration. This helps to maintain community support for foreign investment in Australia, particular1y in the housing market.
The other taxes noted by the petition, such as stamp duty, are levied by the relevant state or territory government, and this query should be directed to them.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
