from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Andrew Leigh
Child Abuse
Dear Chair
Regarding Petition number EN4603, presented on 6 February 2023, I note the following:

Sport Integrity Australia[1] was established in 2020, to form the lead Federal agency to assist National Sporting Organisations and National Sporting Organisations for People with a Disability to address all threats to the integrity of sport, including child abuse.

The establishment of Sport Integrity Australia was a recommendation of the Royal Commission into Institutions Responses to Child Sexual Abuse and coordinates a nationally consistent approach to all threats to the integrity of sport.
Sport Integrity Australia believes that everyone, at all levels of sport, have the right to participate free from all forms of abuse and harm.

Sport Integrity Australia takes all allegations of abuse in sport seriously, and the Integrity Complaints team triage and respond to all current child safeguarding concerns under the National Integrity Framework.

The National Integrity Framework consists of a suite of policies developed in consultation with sports and other key stakeholders, relating to all integrity areas in sport, including Child Safeguarding. The Policies are currently under review, and we are seeking feedback from sports to ensure they are effective and fit-for-purpose across the sector.

While the remit of Sport Integrity Australia does not encompass addressing historical abuse in the sporting sector, the agency has identified the need to provide an avenue for those who have lived experience of abuse in sport, to share their story and be heard. On

31 January 2023, Sport Integrity Australia established the Safe Sport Hotline (1800 161 361), an independent support line to effectively hear concerns and refer to appropriate support services, as required. These referrals could include statutory agencies, such as law enforcement and child protection.

Historically, there have been barriers to sporting participants coming forward with their stories, for fear of victimisation or not being believed. Sport Integrity Australia now provides the safety and function, as well as education and awareness, for those with lived experience of abuse in sport to come forward and be heard.
Sport Integrity Australia will continue to work collaboratively with all stakeholders to ensure sport is safe and fair for all participants.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
[1] It should be noted that the Australian Sports Commission is a separate entity to Sport Integrity Australia.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Sport, Anika Wells

subdebateinfo.title: Food and Grocery Industry: Australian Owned Produce

p.span: Food and Grocery Industry: Australian Owned Produce
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4636 on the diversity of Australian owned products within the food and grocery sector. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

While the Government notes the concerns raised in the petition, it does not have current plans to require food retailers and wholesalers to prominently display Australian owned products or provide special consideration for shelf space positions.

The Country of Origin Food Labelling Information Standard 2016 (Food Labelling Standard) requires most foods offered for retail sale to have information on the country where the food was grown, produced or made. Australian consumers can choose to buy Australian owned products by checking the label.

The Food and Grocery Code of Conduct (the Code) exists to regulate the commercial dealings of retailers and wholesalers with their suppliers to ensure a minimum standard of conduct in the food retail industry. The Code does not seek to intervene in the commercial decisions of retailers or wholesalers regulated by the Code. The broad effectiveness of the Code is scheduled for review later this year.

The Government notes that any interventions in the commercial dealings of retailers and wholesalers need to balance a range of factors, including potential impacts on transparency, competition, and the cost of living for Australian consumers.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Andrew Leigh
Aged Care
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 regarding petition EN4652 requesting consideration of more flexible for small rural aged care services such as the Allambi Elderly Peoples Home in Dimboola.

Ensuring that, wherever possible, aged care facilities have a registered nurse (RN) on site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week (24/7) by July 2023, is a key component of the Australian Government's plan to improve aged care.

This policy was a direct recommendation of the Royal Commission into Aged Care Quality and Safety (Royal Commission). The Royal Commission identified staffing levels (particularly RN staffing levels) are vital to the quality of residential care that older Australians receive and recommended a minimum care time responsibility (initially set at 200 minutes per resident per day) and a requirement to have an RN on-site and on duty 24/7 be introduced.

I note that in line with the request of petition EN4652 there is some flexibility regarding the 24/7 RN responsibility for small rural and remote facilities such as the Allambi Elderly Peoples Home. As was announced in the October 2023 Budget, exemptions to the 24/7 RN responsibility are available to facilities in Modified Monash Model (MMM) 5-7 areas of 30 or less operation places that are able to demonstrate that they have appropriate alternative clinical arrangements in place for the times an RN is not on-site and on duty.

These exemption criteria are in place until 1 July 2024. The Department of Health and Aged Care is undertaking work to explore the feasibility of developing a model of aged care RN workforce shortages by region, and clinically appropriate alternative models of care to ensure safe and quality care is delivered when an RN is not available. This work, combined with information collected through providers' monthly 24/7 RN reporting, may be used to inform future exemption policy decisions and arrangements from 1 July 2024.

In addition to this the Aged Care Quality and Safety Commission (Commission) has indicated that in instances where providers cannot maintain an adequate number of sufficiently skilled staff due to external workforce challenges, it is expected they will have deployed strategies (including alternative clinical care arrangements) to ensure the care needs, and particularly the clinical care needs, of residents are met at all times.

When engaging with a provider about their compliance with workforce-related responsibilities, including the 24/7 RN requirement, the Commission will consider the circumstances of the specific residential facility, and the steps the provider has taken to fulfil its responsibilities. This will include consideration of the efforts made to recruit and retain RN staff, and the clinical governance and alternative clinical care arrangements in place at a facility to ensure the clinical care needs of care recipients are met.

Where a provider demonstrates they are actively working to comply with their responsibilities, the regulatory response will be different from the action taken if a provider is unable to demonstrate a suitable response or deliberately avoids its obligations and may be placing consumers at risk of harm.
The Commission will be releasing further information on their regulatory approach to workforce responsibilities, including the 24/7 RN responsibility shortly.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mark Butler
General Practitioners: Registration
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN4677 seeking to substitute the Pre- Employment Structured Clinical Interview (PESCI) and supervision for the Australian Medical Council's (AMC's) clinical examination as a pathway to general registration for international medical graduates {IMGs). I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Medical Board of Australia (MBA) is responsible for the regulation of the medical profession in Australia, including determining the requirements for registration. The MBA is an independent body established by complementary legislation enacted in each state and territory and neither I nor the Australian Government is able to intervene in its regulatory processes.

The MBA contracts the AMC to deliver certain functions, including the assessment of IMGs, on its behalf. The AMC's clinical exam is one of two pathways available the IMG's seeking general registration on the MBA's standard pathway may use. IMGs may also seek to participate in a Workplace Based Assessment.·

The aim of the AMC clinical exam is to assess an IMG's knowledge and skills to determine if they are equivalent to an Australian trained doctor. IMGs from all medical specialties are required to complete the AMC clinical exam to be granted general registration. The PESCI serves a different purpose. It is a structured interview designed to determine if a proposed employment offer (including support and supervision elements) is suitable for a
non-specialist IMG seeking limited or provisional registration to work in general practice.

The PESCI was developed to address the unique challenges presented in primary care and ensures IMGs can safely service the local community as they progress on their journey to become a specialist general practitioner. The PESCI and the AMC clinical exam are both distinct, critical assessment functions within the registration process and cannot be substituted.

While the Government is unable to intervene in specific regulatory processes, there is currently work underway to identify opportunities to ease the workforce pressures faced by the Australian heath system.

In 2022 Australian Health Ministers established a Health Workforce Taskforce that will, in part, be responsible for developing and overseeing the implementation of a suite of short, medium, and long-term strategies that will ensure a sufficient and sustainable health workforce is in place to meet the healthcare needs of Australians.

The Government is working closely with state and territory governments and the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency on several measures to streamline and accelerate skills and qualification recognition while maintaining an appropriate level of safety and quality with the aim to improve the timeliness of registration processes that will help overseas trained health practitioners come to work in Australia.

In addition, National Cabinet has commissioned an independent review of the regulatory settings relating to health practitioner registration and qualification recognition for overseas trained health professionals and international students who have studied in Australia. The review is currently underway and is being led by Ms Robyn Kurk AO. A report will be delivered to National Cabinet in July 2023. Further information about the review is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au/independent- review-of-health-practitioner-regulatory-settings.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mark Butler
Child Care
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023, in relation to Petition EN4680 on early childhood education and care (ECEC) providers charging fees when children are absent due to illness.

The Australian Government understands the cost-of-living pressures families are facing, and has committed to reducing the cost of ECEC to support working families to get ahead. That is why from July 2023, the Government will increase the Child Care Subsidy (CCS) rate for around 96 per cent of Australian families using ECEC earning less than $530,000—around 1.2 million families.

Under the CCS when a child is absent from a session of care they would normally attend, their family can get CCS for up to 42 days per child per financial year (52 days in 2022-23, due to the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic). These absences can be taken for any reason, including when children are sick, without the need for families to provide documentation. Where families have used all their standard absences, they may be able to access additional absences for a reason defined in the Family Assistance Law and where evidence is provided.

While the Government plays an important role in assisting families with the cost of ECEC, fee charging practices are commercial decisions made by ECEC providers and are not prescribed under the Family Assistance Law. However, the Department of Education closely monitors ECEC fees to ensure the Government's investments are passed on to families. Further, the Government has directed the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to hold an inquiry into ECEC prices. The ACCC will deliver its interim report to the Government by 30 June 2023 and a final report by 31 December 2023.

The Government has also tasked the Productivity Commission to undertake a comprehensive inquiry into Australia's ECEC system. The inquiry will make recommendations to support affordable, accessible, equitable and high-quality ECEC, with the final report provided to the Government by 30 June 2024.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Early Childhood Education, Anne Aly
Middle East
Dear Ms Templeman,
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March enclosing a petition (EN4681) regarding the question of Palestinian statehood.

The Albanese Government's approach is guided by the principle of advancing the cause of peace and progress toward a just and enduring two-state solution. We believe the conflict is a matter that must be resolved through negotiations between the parties, and that viewing the conflict from just one perspective will not achieve peace and any lasting solution to the Middle East conflict cannot be at the expense of either Palestinians or Israelis.

The Albanese Government is taking steps consistent with these overarching principles. We have reaffirmed Australia's previous longstanding and bipartisan position that Jerusalem is a final status issue that should be resolved through peace negotiations.

In recognition of the vital work the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA) undertakes, the Albanese Government has doubled its funding to the organisation from $10 million to $20 million this financial year. UNRWA is the only organisation that has the mandate and central role to provide relief and social services to Palestinian refugees in the region. We will continue Australia's long-term support of UNRWA until there is a just and sustainable solution to the refugee situation.

We are also rebalancing Australia's position in international forums. The Albanese Government has shifted five votes related to Israel and the Palestinian Territories in the UN General Assembly's main committees, including on the operations of UNRWA, Palestinian refugees' properties, Israeli settlements, and the right of the Palestinian people to self- determination.

Australia does not support unilateral actions that reduce the prospects for peace, inflame tensions and prevent Israelis and Palestinians from the full enjoyment of their fundamental human rights, a view the Australian Government expressed at the Human Rights Council on 6 March.

Settlements are an obstacle to peace. At Senate Estimates on 16 February 2022, I associated Australia with the joint statement made by the Foreign Ministers of France, Germany, Italy, the United States, and the United Kingdom on the Israeli government's announcement that it is advancing nearly 10,000 settlement units and intends to begin a process to normalise nine outposts previously deemed illegal under Israeli law.
The Albanese Government's approach is guided by the principle of advancing the cause of peace and progress toward a just and enduring two-state solution.
Thank you for your correspondence and ongoing interest in the matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Penny Wong
COVID-19: Testing
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 regarding petition number EN4688.

The Australian Government is committed to supporting effective COVID-19 testing to limit the spread and ensure that those most at risk of severe disease, including people with complex underlying health conditions and the immunocompromised, have fast access to care and treatments.

Access to COVID-19 PCR tests funded under the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) has not changed throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. A request (referral) from a medical or nurse practitioner has always been a requirement for MBS funded COVID-19 tests (like all other MBS funded pathology tests). A request for a pathology test, including a COVID-19 test, can be made through a telehealth consultation.

A clinician cannot get authority to issue a prescription for antivirals without a result. In order to expedite treatment with antivirals, a telehealth consultation is an alternative approach to ensure that the patient can provide a positive rapid antigen test (RAT) and receive the appropriate prescription without delay. If the treating practitioner determines an in-person consultation and_ traditional pathology test is necessary, a written request for the associated pathology service must be provided.

During the pandemic, COVID-19 PCR testing without the need for a request has been conducted by states and territories. The National Partnership on COVID-19 Response has provided states and territories with funding for PCR testing on a 50:50 cost shared basis. This Partnership ceased on 31 December 2022. In accordance with the testing strategy outlined in the National COVID-19 Health Management Plan (National Plan) for 2023, from 1 January 2023, the new National Partnership for Priority Populations for Testing and Vaccination provides funding to states and territories on a 50:50 cost-shared basis to target PCR testing to those most at risk of severe COVID-19 and death, including the
-immunocompromised. Under both the previous and the new National Partnership arrangements, people do not need a referral to access a PCR test through a state and territory testing clinic.

In recent months some state and territory governments have wound "back these COVID-19 testing sites and have prioritised free PCR testing for vulnerable persons who are at risk for severe COVID-19 disease and who are eligible for access to antiviral treatments.

The National Plan outlines the current Government health supports to manage COVID-19 over 2023. The National Plan reflects a consistent approach across Australia, agreed by National Cabinet on 30 September 2022, to transition the COVID-19 response with a priority to minimise the incidence of death and severe illness, particularly focusing on those most at risk. The National Plan is available to view on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au by searching for 'National COVID-19 Health Management Plan for 2023'.

Medicare does not cover medical supplies. For example, Medicare does not fund bandages or medicines. Medicare provides rebates for clinical services provided by medical practitioners such as the COVID-19 PCR diagnostic tests provided by pathologists (who are medical specialist doctors) within an Australian laboratory accredited by the National Association of Testing Authorities.

The Government continues to ensure the availability of RATs for vulnerable groups including Australia's First Nations people and Commonwealth supported residential aged care homes. Since May 2022, the Government has deployed more than 73.2 million RATs from the National Medical Stockpile.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mark Butler
Floods: New South Wales
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 6 March 2023 enclosing Petition EN4701, with 11 signatures, related to disaster relief funding for the local government area (LGA) of Cabonne in NSW.

State and territory governments have primary responsibility for responding to disasters and providing immediate assistance to impacted communities. The Australian Government supports the states with the costs of providing relief and recovery assistance to communities through the jointly-funded Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements (DRFA).

Under the DRFA, jurisdictions determine the type and level of assistance to make available following a disaster. Importantly jurisdictions are not bound by the DRFA, and can make available whatever assistance they deem necessary, regardless of whether it is eligible for cost sharing under the DRFA. This recognises that states and territories are best placed to identify the type and level of assistance to make available following a disaster, in accordance with their responsibility for disaster management.

In recognition of the devastating impacts of the flooding commencing on 4 August 2022 in Southern and Central West NSW and the flooding commencing on 14 September 2022 across NSW, a wide range of assistance has been made available under the DRFA. Cabonne is a declared LGA for both events and accordingly, residents are able to access assistance that has been offered.
The following standard recovery assistance measures is being jointly-funded by the NSW and Commonwealth Governments under the DRFA:
Personal hardship and distress assistance.
Counter disaster operations.
Restoration of essential public assets.
Concessional interest rate loans for small businesses, primary producers and non-profit organisations who have suffered direct damage.
Freight subsidies for primary producers.
Grants for non-profit organisations.
The Australian and NSW Governments have committed to cost-share the following extraordinary recovery assistance under the DRFA:
Central West caravan and modular housing program.
Primary producer recovery grants of up to $75,000 for eligible primary producers to help with recovery and reinstatement activities.

Rural landholders grants of up to $10,000 for impacted landholders, not eligible for assistance under existing support mechanisms, for clean-up activities, damages or losses beyond the vicinity of the residential dwelling.
Small business and non-profit organisation recovery grants of up to $50,000 for eligible small businesses and non-profit organisations to help with recovery and reinstatement activities.
Local government recovery grants for funding assistance to local governments to assist them in undertaking immediate recovery activities, address emerging needs and help build community resilience.
Clean-up assistance program for clean-up of properties, waste transfer and disposal, and clean-up and restoration of public, community and environmental asset.
In addition, the following assistance measures have been made available for highly impacted LGAs, including Cabonne:
Back Home grants of up to $20,000 to help pay for costs towards restoring housing to a habitable condition or replacing essential household items.
Rental Support Scheme to contribute to the cost of 16 weeks rental support for eligible applicants to ensure households can secure accommodation.
Property Damage Assessment program for the assessment of properties and demolition of those found to be uninhabitable.

These assistance measures are administered by the NSW Government, in accordance with the DRFA. Further information can be found through the Service NSW website: https://www.service.nsw.gov.au/floods or by calling 13 77 88.

In addition to the jointly funded assistance available under the DRFA, I have activated the Australian Government Disaster Recovery Payment (AGDRP) and Disaster Recovery Allowance (DRA) in the Cabonne LGA. The AGDRP is available to people who have either been seriously injured by the disaster, are the immediate family member of someone who has died or is missing due to the event or have sustained major damage to their home (principle place of residence) or major assets. The DRA is a form of short-term income support that is available to employees, primary producers and sole traders who have lost income as a direct result of the severe weather and flooding. AGDRP and DRA are delivered by Services Australia.
The Australian Government continues to work closely with the NSW Government to understand emerging recovery needs and ensure necessary assistance is provided to affected communities.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4701 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Emergency Management, Murray Watt

subdebateinfo.title: Health Care: Drug and Alcohol Rehabilitation

p.span: Health Care: Drug and Alcohol Rehabilitation
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 regarding petition number EN4704, concerning regulation over private alcohol and drug rehabilitation treatment centres.

The National Quality Framework for Drug and Alcohol Treatment Services (National Quality Framework) was published by the Department of Health and Aged Care on 2 December 2019, following endorsement by all governments through the Ministerial Drug and Alcohol Forum. The National Quality Framework sets a nationally consistent quality benchmark for all providers of drug and alcohol treatment services and includes strong clinical governance requirements and a list of acceptable accreditation standards for drug and alcohol specialist treatment service providers to meet.

All providers of drug and alcohol treatment services must comply with the National Quality Framework. To be compliant with the National Quality Framework, providers of drug and alcohol treatment services must have accreditation from at least one of the accreditation standards outlined in the National Quality Framework.

While governance of the National Quality Framework is a shared responsibility between state and territory and Commonwealth governments, the implementation and monitoring of compliance is largely the responsibility of state and territory governments.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mark Butler
International Relations: Australia and China
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 enclosing Petition EN4711, with six signatures, concerning China's application to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP).

The current priority for CPTPP Parties is to advance the accession process for the United Kingdom. UK accession negotiations reached a significant milestone on 31 March 2023, with the announcement of substantial conclusion. However further work continues to finalise this process. CPTPP members are focused on maintaining a strong accession precedent, which is in all our interests.

With respect to future accessions, Australia will work with the CPTPP membership to consider applications on a consensus basis, in accordance with the accession guidelines. It is vital that we maintain the high standards of the CPTPP with any acceding economy. An economy that seeks to accede to the CPTPP must demonstrate that it can meet, implement and adhere to the rules and standards of the Agreement and have a demonstrated track record of complying with trade commitments.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Penny Wong
Medicinal Cannabis
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 regarding petition number EN4713.

As Australia is a signatory to the international drug conventions, the Australian cannabis and cannabis product laws align with the controls outlined by the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs of 1961and the Convention on Psychotropic Substances of 1971.

Access by the public to medicinal cannabis products is controlled in Australia through a classification process known as 'scheduling'. Medicines and chemicals are classified into schedules in the legislative instrument known as the Poisons Standard according to the level of regulatory control over the availability of the medicine or chemical required to protect public health and safety. Under scheduling, the overwhelming majority of medicinal cannabis products are prescription only medicines, thus requiring prescription by an Australian registered medical practitioner.

While there are two medicinal cannabis products which have received regulatory approval by the TGA, the majority of patient access to medicinal cannabis products in Australia is permitted through the Special Access Scheme (SAS) and Authorised Prescriber (AP) scheme. Access to unapproved products require specific approvals by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and qualified prescribers to determine the clinical appropriateness for prescribing medicinal cannabis products. The TGA will not approve prescription of medicinal cannabis products under unapproved medicines access pathways if there are safety concerns such as if the doses of the products or the nominated patient is inappropriate for the particular product.

To improve transparency and data accessibility, the TGA also publishes on its website de-identified data on SAS approvals and notifications and AP approvals specific to unapproved medicinal cannabis products.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mark Butler
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 regarding petition number EN4716, which proposed changes to sick leave.

The Fair Work Act 2009 (the Act) does not specify what type of evidence of personal/carer's leave needs to be given by an employee, only that the evidence must satisfy a reasonable person. Depending on the circumstances, reasonable evidence may include alternatives to a medical certificate from a doctor, such as a leave certificate from a pharmacy or a statutory declaration. Further information about providing evidence for sick leave can be found on the website of the Fair Work Ombudsman: www.fairwork.gov.au/leave/sick-and-carers-leave/paid-sick-and-carers- leave/notice-and-medical-certificates.

With respect to the request that the annual sick leave entitlement be increased from 10 days to 12 days, nothing in the Act prevents an employer and employees negotiating a workplace agreement that has conditions that go above the safety net established by the National Employment Standards, including for example to provide for greater amounts of sick leave and quicker accrual or crediting of sick leave. Employers and employees can also negotiate about the type of medical evidence required to support sick leave, the frequency with which it is required, and payment for medical examinations.

With respect to the request that sick leave be paid into a collective pool for employees that they can access throughout their career, I can advise that the Australian Government has committed to consulting with state and territory governments, unions and industry to develop, where it is practical, portable entitlement schemes for Australians in insecure work. The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations is currently undertaking planning to progress these consultations which will inform any subsequent policy.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Tony Burke
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 regarding petition EN4744, requesting the Australian Government to reverse the $0.50 indexation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) concessional card co-payment.

The Australian Government is committed to easing cost-of-living pressures and ensuring that all Australians are able to access high quality health care, including prescription medicines, through the PBS. The PBS is a key component of Medicare, providing significant direct assistance—$14.7 billion in 2021-22—to make medicines affordable for Australians.

Medicines supplied under the PBS are subject to a patient contribution, known as a co-payment. The co-payment is the amount the patient pays towards the cost of their PBS medicines and assists in its sustainability. While many PBS medicines cost significantly more than the patient contribution, the co-payment for 2023 that applies to Commonwealth concessional entitlement cardholders is $7.30.

Under legislation, the amount is automatically indexed on an annual basis, in line with the Consumer Price Index (CPI). The CPI increase for 2023 for the concessional co-payment was $0.50, which equates to an additional $18.00 for full priced prescriptions before the PBS Safety Net threshold is reached, beyond which concessional patients receive free PBS medicines for the balance of the calendar year.

The concessional co-payment remains less than one quarter of the general co-payment amount of $30.00 paid by Australians who do not hold a concession card. Pharmacists also have the option to discount the patient co-payment further by up to $1.00, which means that many concessional patients will pay no more than $6.30 for the cost of a PBS medicine in 2023.

The Government understands that for some patients and families who need a lot of medicines each year, the cost can be significant. The PBS Safety Net scheme protects patients and their families from incurring excessive costs in relation to the supply of medicines. The concessional safety net threshold in 2023 is $262.80.
The Government reduced the PBS Safety Net thresholds in 2022 and as an ongoing benefit of this, the concessional safety net amount is now the lowest it has been since 2006.

A concession card holder can reach the PBS Safety Net threshold after 36 prescriptions and become eligible to receive PBS medicines free for the balance of the calendar year (plus any applicable premiums that may apply).

The Government recognises that there are general patients who are often on low to middle incomes that may not meet the requirements to be a concession cardholder. These general patients were paying a significantly higher price for medicines than concessional patients. That is why on 1 January 2023, for the first time in 75 years, the general patient co-payment was reduced to $30.00, down from $42.50 in 2022.
The Government does not have any further amendments to the co-payment or PBS Safety Net threshold for concessional or general patients to announce at this time.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mark Butler
Biosecurity
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 March 2023 concerning petition number EN4756 about the revised requirements for the importation of dogs and cats into Australia.
Rabies is a terrible disease; it kills about 60,000 people around the world every year, so it is essential that we keep Australia rabies-free.

The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has an important role in assessing and managing the biosecurity risks associated with the import of a range of goods from overseas. Regular reviews are undertaken, and risk analyses may be conducted, in response to new information about biosecurity risks, or to an import permit application.

I note that the petition includes 2 requests relating to the department's recent review of the rabies virus risk in imported dogs, cats and canine semen from approved countries. Addressing the first request to 'Pause the implementation of the revised import requirements for domesticated animal (dog/cats) until such time as the department can prove that they have the mechanisms in place from foreign government to properly and timely support the identification of pets', I am able to advise that the department has been engaging with trading partners since the draft review was released in October 2022. This has resulted in bilaterally agreed country specific identity declarations or use of the model certification by countries representing 85 per cent of imports.

The department will continue the implementation and continues working closely with trading partners to ensure the biosecurity risks associated with rabies are managed. Since the last policy review in 2013, there has been growing commercialisation of the companion animal trade.
Many countries, including Australia, have reported increases in fraudulent certification for cat and dog imports.

Addressing the second request to 'Recognise all existing Post Entry Quarantine (PEQ) bookings made under the previous incumbent import conditions at the time the import permits were issued, and ... the validity of the RNATT testing window of 24 months, and the incumbent 10 days PEQ stay.for all pets entering Australia', I can advise that all existing PEQ bookings remain in place and are not subject to change as a result of the new policy. In addition, the department decided not to vary existing import permits that were valid when the new policy was finalised. This means that individuals who had an approved import permit for a cat or a dog prior to the release of the final policy review may import their animal into Australia subject to the import conditions outlined in their permit, including the acceptance of an RNATT with 24 month validity and requirement of a minimum 10-day post-entry quarantine period.

Transitional arrangements have also been agreed for managing applications submitted prior to 1 March 2023 that had not yet been finalised, providing options for people to import their cats and dogs to Australia whilst balancing the biosecurity risks with the need for fairness and equity.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me and for the valuable work undertaken by the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Emergency Management, Murray Watt
Climate Change: Rail Transport Infrastructure
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 20 March 2023 regarding petition EN4759 in relation to rail freight electrification.

The Australian Government has set ambitious emission reduction targets for which strong action will be required across all transport modes. Our net zero task for transport will be undertaken in a planned and coordinated way to ensure we can take up economic and productivity opportunities, while carefully managing the transition to new energy sources for our transport sector.

A Net Zero Unit has been established in the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts to identify how the infrastructure portfolio can work across government and with industry to help achieve net zero and improve the resilience of our transport networks and supply chains.

The Government's ambition is to embrace opportunities for sustainable growth in the rail industry, growing jobs, expanding our manufacturing base and delivering a cleaner environment. The National Rail Action Plan (NRAP) outlines a commitment between Australian governments and industry to boost rail safety and productivity. NRAP has three priority areas; addressing skills and labour shortages, harmonising rules and standards across jurisdictions, and advancing interoperability of freight and passenger rail.
Given the rail sector's low relative emission rates, increases in productivity will have flow on sustainability effects as it supports the increased competitiveness of rail.

Additionally, under NRAP the Rail Industry Safety and Standards Board has developed national standards for energy storage and emissions from diesel powered passenger trains, with the aim of creating an environmentally cleaner rail industry.
Thank you for bringing the petition to my attention. I trust this information will be of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Catherine King
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email sharing a petition for increased Australian military support to Ukraine.

Australia is proud to have committed approximately $680 million in important defence, economic and emergency humanitarian assistance to Ukraine. This has included approximately $510 million in defensive military assistance to Ukraine, including 90 Australian-built Bushmaster vehicles.

On 24 February, the Australian Government announced it will provide additional Uncrewed Aerial Systems (UAS) to Ukraine. Australia, with France, will also jointly manufacture 155mm NATO-standard ammunition. This assistance makes a meaningful contribution to Ukraine's defence, empowering Ukraine to resolve this conflict on its own terms.

Australia is committed to strengthening the global rules-based order, and is a ready and able partner for all countries that seek a peaceful an prosperous world, where sovereignty and territorial integrity is respected. Balancing our national priorities and regional commitments, we will continue to support Ukraine and assess all formal assistance requests from Ukraine on a case-by-case basis.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Penny Wong(Petition No. EN4763)
Australian National Anthem
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter dated 20 March 2023 regarding petition EN4766 which requests that the Australian Government change the Australian National Anthem to 'I Am Australian'.
The words and tune of the Australian National Anthem were proclaimed by the
Governor-General of Australia on 19 April 1984, after extensive surveys of national opinion, starting in the 1970s. On 1 January 2021, the second line of the Anthem changed from
'For we are young and free' to 'For we are one and free.' This change was made to represent all Australians.
The Australian National Anthem remains widely accepted by Australians and it identifies Australia at home and overseas but anyone can enjoy other songs about Australia such as 'I Am Australian'.

While the Government has no plans to change this important national symbol at this time, debate around these matters in the wider community should be celebrated and encouraged as an important part of our democracy.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Patrick Gorman
Health Care
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 March 2023 regarding petition number EN4775 on banning companies convicted of carrying out illegal gain-of-function research.

I note that the petition refers to public comments about Pzifer intentionally mutating viruses in order to develop tailored vaccines. I can reassure you that Australia's framework for the regulation and oversight of life sciences research, including gain-of-function research, is comprehensive. In some areas Australia's regulatory framework is more extensive than in other countries. For example, unlike Canada and the USA, Australia has specific legislation for laboratory-based research with genetically-modified organisms and the Gene Technology Regulator certifies facilities undertaking such research. Australia's approach to health security has also been recognised internationally for its capabilities to prevent, detect and prepare for biosecurity and biosafety risks.

Australia's framework for the regulation and oversight of life sciences research includes a combination of Commonwealth and state/territory legislation, national standards and guidance, as well as local institutional governance and practices. Management of research integrity in Australia relies on a system of self-regulation by research institutions (including universities) within this national framework.

There are additional controls for, and oversight of, research involving infectious agents and research involving genetically modified organisms including requirement for licences, monitoring and reporting to government bodies for.some research. Ethics and safety approvals (including biosafety and biosecurity) from government bodies and/or institutional committees that encompass consideration of the risks and benefits of the research may also apply.

The legislative controls include provisions for action on any contravention of the legislation. The application of this framework to potential gain-of-function research is outlined in Figure 4 on page 23 of the National Health and Medical Research Council's Gain-of-Function Research Review Report (March 2022) available at www.nhmrc.gov.au/about- us/publications/gain-function-research-review-report.

Further details on the elements of the framework, relevant legislation and responsible agencies, and institutional controls are provided in Table 5 (starting on page 24 of the report). The relevant figure and table are also attached.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mark Butler
Health Care
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 March 2023 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions regarding petition number EN4778 to restrict energy drink sales for persons under 16 years of age.

Caffeine is a mild stimulant, and is found in many natural sources, such as tea leaves, coffee beans, and cocoa, but can also be added to processed foods, such as cola drinks, sports supplements and energy drinks.

The Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (Code) restricts how much caffeine can be added to energy drinks and cola-type soft drinks. Currently, the Code (Standard 2.6.4) specifies that a formulated caffeinated beverage (an energy drink) must contain no more than 320mg/L of total caffeine, from any source. For reference, this concentration is similar to the amount of caffeine in a cup of instant coffee. Standard 2.6.4 also outlines the labelling requirements for energy drinks, this includes the requirement for products to carry a statement to the effect that the food is not recommended for children, pregnant or lactating women and individuals sensitive to caffeine.
The Code includes labelling requirements for other foods containing added caffeine.

Foods containing added caffeine must have a statement on the label that the product contains caffeine. Foods containing guarana (a South American plant with high levels of natural caffeine) must also be labelled as containing caffeine. This is to help people avoid caffeine either for themselves or their children.

There is no recognised health-based guidance, such as an Acceptable Daily Intake level for caffeine. A Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) working group found evidence for increased anxiety levels in children at intakes of about 3 mg of caffeine per kilogram of bodyweight per day. This amount for children aged 9-13 corresponds to a caffeine intake of 120 mg per day (approximately two cans of cola).

While research undertaken by FSANZ has confirmed that caffeine intakes in the general population remain at appropriate levels, it is recognised that the food consumption data used for this dietary intake assessment came from the 2011-12 Australian National Nutrition and Physical Activity Survey and may not reflect current consumption patterns.
The next national nutrition survey is currently underway which will inform a new assessments of caffeine intakes in the -population.

FSANZ is currently reviewing (through Proposal P1056) the permissions for caffeine in sports foods and general foods. This review is considering the risk caffeine poses to sensitive sub-populations such as children. This work includes several public consultation periods, the first of these closed on 13 February 2023.

FSANZ is currently considering these submissions which will help inform the final regulatory recommendations for caffeine. Any regulatory recommendations, including proposed drafting for the Code, will be provided in the second round of consultation to be released later this year.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mark Butler
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email dated 20 March 2023, concerning Petition EN4783 relating to the cancellation of the Cashless Debit Card (CDC) in the Ceduna region.

As you are aware, the Australian Government has delivered on their election commitment to abolish the CDC across Australia. This commitment was implemented through the SocialSecurity (Administration) Amendment (Repeal of Cashless Debit Card and Other Measures) Act 2022, which ceased the compulsory CDC in the regions of Ceduna, East Kimberley, Goldfields, and Bundaberg and Hervey Bay region.

The evidence on the CDC program was not conclusive. The last evaluation of the program reported both positive and negative findings, and the Australian National Audit Office found that the program did not demonstrate that it met its objectives.

Since early October 2022, former CDC participants in Ceduna, East Kimberley, Goldfields and Bundaberg and Hervey Bay regions have been able to opt out of the CDC program, or volunteer should they feel this option more appropriate for their circumstances.
On 6 March 2023, those who have volunteered and current CDC participants in the Northern Territory and Cape York and Doomadgee region transferred to enhanced Income Management (IM).

Enhanced IM utilises a contemporary card (known as the SmartCard), which preserves the financial functionality that participants are familiar with through the CDC. Under enhanced IM, participants retain their current physical card until they receive their SmartCard. However, IM program rules apply, such as restricting purchases of alcohol, gambling, tobacco products or pornography.

The Government is committed to consulting on the future of the IM program with a wide range of stakeholders, including First Nations leaders, women's groups, service providers, communities, people receiving welfare payments, and state and territory governments on the future of IM across Australia. IM and enhanced IM will remain in place until this consultation is complete.

During my consultations in the Ceduna region in June 2022, the importance of continuing support services, access to supports for crisis and capacity building, as well as pathways from welfare to employment and economic independence were discussed. As a result of this feedback, on 24 September 2022, I announced the Government will provide up to $17 million for community-led and designed initiatives to support employment opportunities and economic independence in former CDC regions. Successful initiatives will commence from June 2022 and be delivered through to 2024-25, with additional funding and extension of existing support services and the Local Partner program to 30 June 2024.

The Government, through the Department of Health and Aged Care, will also deliver $49.9 million for additional alcohol and other drug treatment services and support in the Bundaberg and Hervey Bay, Ceduna, East Kimberley and Goldfields regions. These services will be co-designed with the local community to ensure the supports meet local needs.

The Government is committed to continue consultations with First Nations communities, affected communities and individuals about what the future of IM looks like for them. Consultations are covering what support is required, as well as co-designing strategies with communities to address long-term challenges including drug and alcohol misuse and problem gambling.

In this regard, my department has developed Local Services Plans to identify service gaps, improve services and address social issues in former CDC locations. My department utilised feedback from consultations with service providers and various stakeholders in the development of these Plans. The Local Services Plans are now available on the department's website at www.dss.gov.au. Further, I have announced funding of $16 million to address the issues identified in these plans. More information on the announcement is available to view at www.ministers.dss.gov.au.

I will continue working with communities to support services and investment to address concerns about anti-social behaviour or other issues in communities. This includes working with communities about what is the best way forward and what types of intervention could reduce social harms.
Thank you again for writing.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Amanda Rishworth
Victoria: Roads
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 20 March 2023 regarding the Sealing Roads in the Dandenong Ranges and Surrounds (Sealing Roads) projects, and providing me with a copy of the petition you presented to the House of Representatives, concerning recent funding reductions to these projects (EN4785).
I note the concerns raised by the community around the condition of unsealed roads across the Cardinia Shire and Yarra Ranges and acknowledge the effect these conditions have on residents.

The 2022-23 October Federal Budget both honoured the Australian Government's election commitments and made necessary adjustments to some existing infrastructure projects to ensure the Infrastructure Investment Program (IIP) can be delivered in a sustainable way.

As you are aware, the Commonwealth's commitment towards the Sealing Roads project has been reduced with uncommitted funding being returned to the Budget. The Department of Infrastructure, Transp01i, Regional Development, Communications and the Alis is working closely with both Councils to ensure that all works currently under construction or contracted will be delivered.

The Australian Government is committed to investing in infrastructure projects that support Victoria's growing cities and regions, which are underpinned by strong supporting evidence and demonstrated value for money. The Australian Government is working closely with the Victorian Government to ensure the investment in road transport infrastructure is sustainable and does not exacerbate market capacity issues.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter and I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Catherine King
PETITIONS
Statements

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:02): Petitions to the House of Representatives give us a glimpse into the issues that are important to Australians at a particular time. The Petitions Committee is always interested to see the diversity of matters submitted to the House by petitioners. Petitions can relate to a general policy area such as action on climate change or can be more specific, such as the listing of a particular medicine under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. In all cases, petitions must make a request of the House on a matter on which the House has the power to act.

Some of the larger petitions presented today include a request to protect the identities of Australian Defence Force personnel under investigation; a request to halt a proposed wind farm off the coast of Port Stephens; and a request to ban gambling advertising on television, radio and online.

There are also a number of petitions related to migration issues this week, including a request to review the processing times under the Business Innovation and Investment Program, a request to remove the need for English language testing for overseas-born, Australian educated graduates for immigration and other purposes, and a request for better visa pathways for parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents.
Each of the petitions presented today is published on the parliamentary website and will be referred to the minister responsible for the matters raised in the petition for a written response.
I thank the House.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Criminal Code Amendment (Prohibition of Nazi Symbols) Bill 2023 [No. 2]

p.span: Criminal Code Amendment (Prohibition of Nazi Symbols) Bill 2023 [No. 2]
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Leeser.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr LEESER (Berowra) (10:05): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

This bill is an affirmation of Australian values—values that respect the equality of Australians from all races, beliefs and backgrounds; the dignity of people with disabilities; the right to freedom of speech; our shared fundamental human dignity that the ideology of Nazism stands against. Nazism today stands against Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, people with disabilities, Jewish Australians, LGBTI Australians and any Australian with a different political view than their own. This bill affirms our values as Australians.

It honours the sacrifices made by Australians made during the Second World War, an entire generation of Australians under the leadership of Robert Menzies, Arthur Fadden, John Curtin and Ben Chifley that stood together to oppose Nazism. Most Australians have a story of an ancestor or ancestors who stood for freedom when it truly mattered. I think of my grandfather, a good man whose ambition was nothing more than to raise a family and run a hardware store. He signed up to defend Australia and stand against Hitler's sick racial ideology and the ideology of imperial Japan. My grandfather paid a terrible price for those convictions, enduring the worst deprivations of the Changi prisoner-of-war camp and the horrific Thai-Burma Railway. Such was the cost for standing against evil. It was a cost paid by nearly 40,000 Australians who made the supreme sacrifice in World War II, as well as a million Australians who served, the families they loved and a generation whose sacrifice was nothing less than complete. With this bill we honour their memory.

I had hoped, and the Leader of the Opposition had hoped, when we worked together on drafting this bill, that it could be another affirming moment of our shared commitment to our great Australian values—values of respect, acceptance and good-heartedness and a fierce determination to stand against an ideology of genocide and death. It's the thing we do most days in this parliament. I'm proud of the work I've done with the member for Wentworth and the member for Macnamara, co-chairing the Parliamentary Friends of the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance. But sadly on this bill we've had only politics. The government blocked debate on this matter in this House almost two months ago. The government recommended through the Senate committee process that an identical bill be voted down, and the government has offered no alternative bill or process. Despite saying two months ago that the government was working on a bill to this effect, where is this bill today?

In the depths of my being I oppose hate speech, racism and anti-Semitism. Because these things are so despicable, we should never throw around accusations about them lightly. It's one of the reasons the Jewish community so strongly opposes casual references to the Holocaust, because you can't be casual about the greatest crime in human history. Yet two months ago the Attorney-General accused the opposition leader, a man who has been our Home Affairs minister and our Minister for Defence, of giving encouragement to neo-Nazis. He accused a man who is not antisemitic of being an antisemite. He accused a party that is not antisemitic of being antisemitic. The Attorney-General should've known better. We were assured then by the Leader of the House, who I believe spoke genuinely, that the government would do something. Instead, two months later we have nothing.

This bill is more than an affirmation of who we are, though affirmations like this are sometimes needed. This bill is more than that. This bill will make Australians safer. The director-general of ASIO, Mike Burgess, warned in his latest annual threat assessment about the increase in grievance based violent extremism and an increase in the radicalisation of young Australians. He said:

As a nation, we need to reflect on why some teenagers are hanging Nazi flags and portraits of the Christchurch killer on their bedroom walls, and why others are sharing beheading videos. And just as importantly, we must reflect on what we can do about it.

ASIO backed these words up with a submission to the Senate committee on this bill. They said the Criminal Code Amendment (Prohibition of Nazi Symbols) Bill would assist law enforcement in early intervention. Let me read from the committee's report:

The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) explained that Nazi symbols play a significant role among nationalist and racist violent extremist groups, both by signalling ideology and in-group belonging, as well as provoking or intimidating ideological opponents. ASIO further explained that symbols are:

… an effective propaganda tool because they are easy to remember and understand. They can transcend language, cultural, and ethnic divides; creating, distributing, and understanding them is not limited to a select few or one cultural or language group.
The report also noted that ASIO contended that symbols served to promote cohesion among some nationalist and racist extremist groups, and provoke their opponents:
Nationalist and Racist Violent Extremists adopt specific imagery and terminology to signal their ideology, build in-group belonging between adherents, and provoke or intimidate ideological opponents.
ASIO made it very clear in its submission to the committee:

ASIO is aware that nationalist and racist groups use hate speech and extremist insignia in their recruitment and profile raising. Globally, there can be links between hate speech and hate motivated crimes, including terrorism. The possession of extremist material has featured in many prosecutions of terrorist offences.
Symbols matter. The Sydney Jewish Museum, quoting British novelist Dion Fortune, made the observation:
"Symbols are to the mind what tools are to the hand". We must deny these extremists access to such symbols—symbols they use to create fear, spread hate and capture new recruits.

Don't think that this is not happening here, right now. Our country is dealing with this today. Look at the front page of this week's Australian Jewish News, where small groups of radicals, not the mainstream in any way, are seeking to conflate the work that I, Mark Liebler and other prominent Jewish Australians have done on the Voice with their anti-Semitic tropes. These small evil groups will seek to exploit our legitimate debate we have on any issue when they see an opening.

I believe this bill has a part to play in our work to keep all Australians safe. Let me turn to what this bill will do. This bill introduces an amendment to the criminal code relating to the prohibition of Nazi symbols. This bill does not make the display of Nazi symbols and the use of explicit Nazi actions, such as the Nazi salute, illegal. A Nazi symbol is a symbol or action commonly associated with the Nazi party and would include the Nazi swastika, Nazi salute, Nazi uniforms, and other types of symbols identified in the ECAJ anti-Semitism report. It would be an offence to display such a symbol without reasonable excuse. The penalty is 100 penalty units or 12 months in imprisonment.

To avoid doubt, the display of a swastika in connection to Buddhism, Hinduism and Jainism does not constitute the display of a Nazi symbol. It should be noted that, in the same way the Nazis looted the belongings of millions, they also misappropriated the legitimate symbols from these faiths. Nothing we seek to do is about perpetuating this misappropriation. And to ensure this prohibition doesn't interfere with the vital work of teaching young people about the evils of the past, there are limitations and carve-outs in terms of genuine educational, scientific and artistic purposes such as films and documentaries, and it doesn't apply to journalism or where symbols are displayed for another purpose in the public interest.

I want to recognise the work undertaken by state governments already. In 2022, New South Wales unanimously passed the Crimes Amendment (Prohibition on Display of Nazi Symbols) Act 2022. In Victoria, the Summary Offences Amendment (Nazi Symbol Prohibition) Act 2022 makes it an offence to intentionally display in public the Nazi swastika. I note that Tasmania is examining how a ban on Nazi salutes can be incorporated into the Police Offences Amendment (Nazi Symbol Prohibition) Bill 2023 before that parliament. I also recognise that Queensland and South Australia have foreshadowed protections against the display of Nazi symbols.

There is no moral ambiguity when it comes to Nazi displays, demonstrations and actions. This bill will ensure there will be no legal ambiguity when it comes to Nazi displays, demonstrations and actions either. Nazism is not just another political viewpoint; it's an evil, an evil whose fundamental tenet is the racial superiority of one group of people over another. Churchill called the ideology of Nazism 'the perverted science'. But it was not a myth without consequence. Six million Jews were murdered, a figure that represented two-thirds of the Jewish population of Europe in its name. It also resulted in the murder of 1.6 million Polish citizens, 5.7 million Soviet citizens, three million Soviet prisoners of war, 312,000 Serbs, 220,000 Roma, 250,000 people with intellectual disabilities living in institutions, 70,000 so-called 'asocial', 1,900 Jehovah's Witnesses, and thousands and thousands of homosexuals and political prisoners.

It was industrial-scale murder the likes of which the world has never seen. It was an ideology of hate that experimented on children, buried people alive, and set furnaces ablaze with the bodies of millions of men, women and children. Every one of them had a name. Every one of them was loved. Every one of them carried within them the essence of human dignity. Every one of them had dreams and aspirations which, in their totality, could brighten the night sky. I have met Holocaust survivors who have withstood unimaginable night terrors and witnessed the unimaginable. I honour them all and those who fought against Hitler and his crimes. I believe there is broad community and political support for this bill.

Citizenship is a moral responsibility; it's a call to participate, to play our part and do our duty not only to our country, but to each other. In March, when we first sought to have this bill debated, I spoke of Katie Popp, a German Australian Catholic who, in a moment of choosing, saved my family in the 1930s. Katie's decision not to turn a blind eye, not to be a bystander because of the risk to herself but to risk all for what is right, is an example that lives through time. It's an example that her generation has left to us. That is what this bill is all about, and I commend the bill to this House.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?
Mr Wood: I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

The SPEAKER: The question is the bill now be read a second time, and the time allocated for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
NOTICES
Postponement

The SPEAKER (10:15): I inform the House that, pursuant to standing order 110, the honourable member for Mayo has postponed notice No. 2 standing in her name. The order of precedence of remaining private members' business notices, as determined by the Selection Committee's report adopted by the House on 10 May 2023, remains unchanged.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Broadcasting Services Amendment (Prohibition of Gambling Advertisements) Bill 2023

p.span: Broadcasting Services Amendment (Prohibition of Gambling Advertisements) Bill 2023
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Ms Daniel.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Ms DANIEL (Goldstein) (10:16): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
The Prime Minister is 'annoyed.'
The opposition leader has 'had enough.'
That's all very well. How about doing something about it then?

The opposition did have nine years, but finally the major parties are listening after years of advocacy from crossbench members for Clark, Mayo, and more recently the member for Curtin and myself and others. Communities want gambling advertising around sport to STOP.
And I mean, stop dead.

A recent three-year study from La Trobe University for the Victorian Responsible Gambling Foundation found that 78 per cent of the 50,000 respondents felt they should be able to watch TV sport with no gambling ads, 87 per cent said teenagers are exposed to too much gambling advertising.
I have two of those teenagers, and it's for them, and others in our communities across Australia, that I speak today.

It is why I am introducing this bill. It is a direct reflection of community sentiment and I thank all of those from within my community of Goldstein and from around the country who have contacted me in support of this bill.
This bill would place an outright ban on gambling advertising on our screens; including broadcast television, pay TV and their respective streaming services, and on radio.
This bill will be followed by the findings of the House of Reps committee inquiry into online gambling.
I hope that this bill, together with the inquiry's forthcoming recommendations under the formidable leadership of the member for Dunkley, can put an end to gambling ads on TV, on radio and online.

The online space is a complex web of algorithms that targets people based on their age, demographic and browsing habits, with gambling ads specifically geared at teenaged boys and young men, but increasingly attempting to draw in young women as well.
Recent moves by platforms like TikTok to adopt subtle gambling promotions to target young people must be dealt with by the government after the inquiry reports.
When it comes to broadcast, like big tobacco, the gambling industry, making millions off the young, the poor and the desperate in our communities, will resist.

But with gambling ads at saturation levels and invading the minds of our young people in ever more insidious ways, to the extent that multis are now of more interest than the games themselves, we must act.

The gambling ad spend in Australia rose from $89.7 million annually in 2011 to $287.2 million in 2021—a 320 per cent increase and grew further to $310 million by last year. TV ads accounted for more than half of the spend, with about 346,000 television ads on free to air alone; that's an average of 948 per day or 39.5 per hour.

Aware of the latest crossbench push on this, the opposition has recently suggested banning gambling ads during sporting events and one hour either side. The evidence shows that this will not fix the problem. In fact, recent policy interventions to restrict the timing and proximity of gambling ads around broadcast sport has only pushed gambling into other programming—including programming that appeals to children like comedy shows and Marvel movies.

The Australian Communications and Media Authority has itself concluded that an effect of restricting gambling ads during live sport after rule changes came into effect in 2018-19 was simply an increase in gambling ads during non-sport programs—especially between six and 10.30 pm when children and teenagers are watching.
Not only that; the total volume of gambling spots increased by no less than 50 per cent between 2016-17, before the rule changes, and 2018-19 once the new regulations came into effect.

Research from Deakin University in 2018 found that young people are highly aware of gambling marketing. 'When we have dinner,' one said, 'the TV is usually on and usually between the news and stuff they do have ads like Sportsbet.'

When asked what should be done about gambling, young people across multiple studies have called on governments and sporting organisations to take greater responsibility for protecting young people from gambling marketing.
In one study, three quarters of young people agreed that sporting codes should do more to prevent young people from being exposed to advertising for gambling on sport.

We are failing these children if we do not act. I have had youth football officials in my electorate of Goldstein tell me directly that they know the boys in their junior teams are actively betting on gambling apps on their phones.
I also know this is happening because I hear my teenaged son and his friends talking about it.
We cannot say we didn't know. And we cannot hide from the community concern about this. I have had an avalanche of positive reaction from across the country to this bill.
The conclusion is obvious: nothing short of a complete ban on gambling advertising will work and meet the increasing concerns of parents and sports fans alike.
This bill seeks to replicate the approach taken to banning tobacco advertising in 1976.
After all, gambling is also a public health issue.

The social cost of gambling in Victoria alone has been estimated at $7 billion a year. Family and relationship problems were the highest cost, followed by emotional and psychological issues, including distress, depression, suicide and violence. Financial harms were only the third-highest cost.
We can change this—after all it hasn't always been this way.

Amazingly, considering how pervasive it is now, sports betting (other than horse racing) wasn't legal in Australia until 1983, via the TAB, and non-government sports betting—such as Sportsbet—wasn't legal until 1993.
Now, just 30 years later, Australians are the biggest gambling losers worldwide.
All of this has happened well inside my own lifetime.
In 1983 I was a schoolgirl living in Perth where my father—a former 100-gamer for Essendon in the VFL—was coaching Subiaco in the WAFL.
I had grown up around football in Tasmania, where my father coached North Launceston to eight straight grand finals, winning five.

Many of my weeknights as a kid were spent eating curried sausages made by the female volunteers, including the legendary Yvonne Morton, in the clubrooms while Dad was training, my weekends sitting on the bonnet of the car on the boundary at what was then York Park, now UTAS Stadium, jumping off to toot the horn when the red and black kicked a goal.
It was a different time to be sure. And we can't turn back the clock to the days when football was about community, not business and money.

But we can remind ourselves that sport is about fun, health, participation and people and its net benefit to society should be positive. That's why we must end gambling ads, and properly tax the gambling industry's betting profits to offset potential revenue loss to sport.
I understand the argument that gambling ads underpin modern sport's economics in Australia—but that's an addiction that as a society we must break.

Because the price we are paying is a generation of young sport lovers who think they aren't part of the gang if they don't bet, who know more about the intricacies of 'multis' than they do about the finer points of the game they are watching.
The price we are paying is in the evidence—that 18-to-24-year-old men are the fastest-growing cohort of problem gamblers; the first cohort to have been exposed to saturation gambling ads as kids.
It's no longer time to hold 'em. It's time to fold 'em.
I commend this bill to the House, and I strongly urge the government to listen to the community concern and to recognise the concern across this chamber and to allow this bill to be debated.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?
Mr Broadbent: I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.
The SPEAKER: The time allocated for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Albanese Government
Ms BYRNES (Cunningham) (10:26): I move:
That this House:
(1) notes that Sunday, 21 May 2023 marks 12 months since the election of the current Government;

(2) acknowledges that after a decade of mismanagement, chaos and neglect by the former Government, this Government is delivering on its election promises and continues to deliver and build on our plan for a better future;
(3) further acknowledges that this Government's second budget handed down during the last sitting week:
(a) provides responsible cost of living relief;
(b) creates more opportunities for Australians; and
(c) builds a more secure economy into the future; and
(4) further notes that this Government is delivering on our plan for a better future in the face of relentless negative opposition from the Liberal-National coalition.

Today I acknowledge the first anniversary of the election of the Albanese Labor government. We've spent the first 12 months of this government cleaning up the mess we inherited and working hard to deliver stronger foundations for a better future for all Australians. Twelve months ago Australia turned away from the coalition's mess and mismanagement and instead chose a government with a positive plan to grow the economy, create new jobs, boost renewable energy and invest in skills and training. It was also on this day that I was elected to represent my local community as the member for Cunningham. Every day since I have been proud to be a member of this Labor government, which governs for all Australians, not just its mates.

There is much more to do. Australia faces many challenges, and our government has been upfront in discussing those with the public. Meanwhile the government has used its first year to address many of these challenges by—and this is a very long list—reviving Medicare and making medicines cheaper; making child care more affordable; acting to reduce carbon emissions and make energy cheaper; driving the transformation to renewable power; funding 20,000 new university places, as well as 180,000 fee-free TAFE places; having a 15 per cent pay rise for workers in the aged-care sector; establishing the $15 billion National Reconstruction Fund to ensure that Australia is a country that makes things; taking the sting out of energy prices and ensuring bill relief of up to $500 for eligible families and $650 for small businesses; supporting an increase in the minimum wage; allocating over $16 billion in renewable energy infrastructure through Rewiring the Nation; investing $200 million in 400 community batteries across the country, including in Warrawong in my electorate; strengthening our international relationships; and restoring the federal budget. Each of those initiatives points to a better future for Australia, and all were needed after nearly 10 lost years of coalition government.

Our Illawarra community and economy will benefit from our government's initiatives. Of particular importance to me is the way in which the Illawarra will benefit from the Albanese government's determination to rebuild and grow Australia's manufacturing base. Alongside growing sectors of our local economy, such as services, education, tourism and renewables, our manufacturers have a strong future. That future is based on recognised strengths in steel, mining and heavy industry, combined with our deepwater port, great education and training facilities, skilled workers, and large and small businesses. All of these attributes are also feeding our thriving renewable energy industry, whether that be battery technology, green and cheap hydrogen production or planning for offshore wind. In the Illawarra we have firms like Sicona Battery Technologies, Green Gravity, EcoJoule and Hysata all working to make the Illawarra a renewable energy powerhouse.
